questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl is brought to the office for vaginal bleeding for three days and mucosal vaginal discharge for one week. The patient was born at full term with normal delivery to non-consanguineous parents. The patient has a history of multiple fractures. She has no surgical history, and she does not take any daily medications. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 95/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 100/66 mm Hg. Weight is at 95th percentile for age, height is at 60th percentile for age, and head circumference is at 66th percentile for age. Skin examination reveals the skin lesions shown below. Breast development is at Tanner stage II and pubic and axillary hair is at Tanner stage I and female genitalia with signs of maturation. Abdominal and cardiopulmonary exams are unremarkable. Labs show elevated growth hormone levels and prepubertal levels of gonadotropins. X-ray of the femur shows cortical thinning and ground-glass radiolucency. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s vaginal bleeding?
 

McCune-Albright syndrome” by Claudia E Dumitrescu, Michael T Collins. Orphanet Journal of Rare Diseases. 3, 12. 2008. Licensed under CC BY 2.0. Reproduced from Wikipedia.
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of precocious puberty, including breast and genitalia maturation and vaginal bleeding. She also has café-au-lait skin lesions and X-ray findings consistent with polyostotic fibrous dysplasia of bone. She is found to have prepubertal levels of luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle stimulating (FSH) and estrogen. She most likely has McCune-Albright syndrome.

Precocious puberty is defined as pubertal development of secondary sexual characteristics before age 8 in biological females and age 9 in biological males. Precocious puberty can be classified as central or peripheral. In peripheral precocious puberty, the HPG axis has not been activated, so lab work will show prepubertal results (i.e. low luteinizing hormone [LH] and follicle-stimulating hormone [FSH] levels with elevated estradiol and testosterone levels).

McCune-Albright syndrome (MAS) is defined as a triad of peripheral precocious puberty, café-au-lait skin pigmentation, and polyostotic fibrous dysplasia of bone (PFD). It is associated with other endocrinopathies, including hyperthyroidism, growth hormone (GH) excess, renal phosphate wasting with or without rickets, and Cushing syndrome. Biological females presenting with premature episodic vaginal bleeding consistent with menstrual bleeding should be evaluated for features of MAS. In MAS, the cafe-au-lait spots have irregular borders with characteristic “coast of Maine” appearance and are often isolated to one side of the body. The skeletal disease (PFD) almost always involves the proximal femurs and the skull base. If the diagnosis of MAS is suspected based on skin findings and lab work consistent with peripheral precocious puberty, then X-rays or CT scans of the affected bones should be performed. If imaging demonstrates expanded bone with a ground glass appearance, this indicates fibrous dysplasia, and together, these findings confirm the diagnosis of MAS.    

Option Analysis

❌ Congenital adrenal hyperplasia:
Incorrect: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency typically presents with virilization and ambiguous genitalia in females and salt wasting. This patient has no signs of virilization or ambiguous genitalia. She has cafe au lait spots, precocious puberty, signs of fibrous dysplasia, and prepubertal level of labs, making McCune Albright syndrome more likely. 
❌ Idiopathic central precocious puberty :
Incorrect: Idiopathic central precocious puberty is the most common cause of central precocious puberty in biological females. Patients present with signs of precocious puberty without neurological signs and symptoms and with pubertal levels of luteinizing hormone (LH), follicle stimulating (FSH), and estrogen. In this patient, the presence of cafe au lait spots, precocious puberty, and signs of fibrous dysplasia with prepubertal level of labs make McCune Albright syndrome more likely.  
✅ McCune Albright syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Neurofibromatosis  :
Incorrect: Patients with neurofibromatosis (NF) present with café-au-lait spots with smooth regular borders resembling the “coast of California” located on the neck and lower back without associated skeletal involvement and with associated optic gliomas and iris hamartomas. This patient has cafe au lait spots with irregular borders, precocious puberty, and signs of fibrous dysplasia with prepubertal level of labs, making McCune Albright syndrome more likely. 
❌ Ovarian tumor:
Incorrect: Patients with ovarian tumors may present with vaginal bleeding and findings of an adnexal or abdominal mass on physical exam. This patient has vaginal bleeding and other signs of precocious puberty with café-au-lait spots, radiological signs of skeletal disease, and prepubertal levels of hormones making McCune Albright syndrome the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents to the office for a routine school physical. The patient looks anxious and says that she has never had a menstrual cycle and is worried. She has noticed that her breasts appear smaller than her peers. There is no history of headaches, smell or visual disturbances, exposure to radiation, or nipple discharge. There is no history of sexual development problems within the family. Height and weight are at the 5th and 50th percentile for her age, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 117/79 mm Hg. Physical examination reveals wide spaced nipples with a webbed neck. Axillary and pubic hair are absent, and the breasts are at Tanner stage I. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Which of the following is the best test to confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 15-year-old girl with delayed puberty and physical exam findings of short stature with wide-spaced nipples and a webbed neck likely has Turner syndrome. Karyotyping should be performed to diagnose Turner syndrome. Turner syndrome is a sex chromosome disorder caused by the loss of part or all of an X chromosome that leads to ovarian insufficiency. Genotypes 45, XO, 45, X with mosaicism, ring chromosome, or 46, XX can lead to Turner syndrome. 

The most consistent characteristic in girls with Turner syndrome is short stature. Turner syndrome often leads to primary hypogonadism, and it is a major cause of premature ovarian failure. Most affected girls have no breast development and primary amenorrhea. Other characteristics include a "shield" chest with the appearance of widely spaced nipples, a short, webbed neck, and cubitus valgus. Neonates may have congenital lymphedema of the hands and feet and webbed neck. Other associations with Turner syndrome include cardiovascular abnormalities such as bicuspid aortic valve and coarctation of the aorta and autoimmune diseases.

Patients with delayed puberty should be evaluated with gonadotropin and sex hormone levels. Because of lack of appropriate development of the ovaries, patients with Turner syndrome can have elevated levels of FSH and LH and low levels of estradiol (i.e., Hypergonadotropic hypogonadism).

Patients with characteristic features of Turner syndrome should have a karyotype analysis. If genotypes 45, XO, 45, X with mosaicism, ring chromosome, or 46, XX are found, the diagnosis of Turner syndrome is confirmed.    

Option Analysis

❌ Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) :
Incorrect: Brain MRI is useful to diagnose CNS tumors in patients with delayed puberty and neurological signs such as headaches or visual disturbances who may have a prolactinoma. This patient’s presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, which can be confirmed with karyotype analysis.  
❌ Insulin growth factor-1 (IGF) level  :
Incorrect: Low insulin growth factor-1 (IGF) level can help diagnose growth hormone deficiency as the cause of delayed puberty. This patient’s presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, which can be confirmed with karyotype analysis.  
✅ Karyotyping :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Prolactin level:
Incorrect: Prolactin levels are used to diagnose hyperprolactinemia and prolactinoma, which can cause delayed puberty. This patient does not have gynecomastia, nipple discharge, or neurological signs suggestive of hyperprolactinemia, making it a less probable cause in this case. 
❌ TSH and free T4 levels:
Incorrect: These tests can be used to diagnose hypothyroidism, which can cause delayed puberty, but this patient’s presentation is consistent with Turner syndrome, which can be confirmed with karyotype analysis.

questions.text:
A 1-day old 3500-g (7.5-lb) newborn girl delivered at term to a 42-year-old primigravida is being evaluated in the nursery. The infant is having difficulty feeding and has had bilious emesis since birth. She does not have a fever, increased work of breathing, or abnormal movements. The infant's parent did not have any prenatal care. She did not drink alcohol or use other recreational substances during the pregnancy. Delivery was uncomplicated, but the infant was noted to have characteristic facial features. Temperature is 37�C (98.6�F), heart rate is 165/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 69/36 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, the infant is noted to have a flat facial profile with almond-shaped eyes and a single palmar crease. The mucous membranes are moist. A prominent murmur is heard on cardiac exam. Pulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. She has poor muscle tones and poor sucking. X-ray of the abdomen is shown below. Given the most like diagnosis, which of the following additional physical exam findings is most likely to be seen?  



Reproduced from Statdx
questions.solution:
Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons. Licensed under the Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported license.    

This newborn patient has features consistent with Down syndrome, including duodenal atresia, a flat face with almond shaped eyes, and a prominent murmur. History reveals an infant born to a mother of advanced age (42-year-old) who has not had prenatal care. Sandal toe gap with a wide space between the first and second toes is another physical that is characteristic of Down syndrome.        

Patients with Down syndrome are usually identified during prenatal screening. Risk factors include advanced maternal age. Physical examination reveals classic facial features, like upslanting palpebral fissures, epicanthal folds, a flat facial profile, brachycephaly and low-set small ears. Patients may also have a short neck with excessive skin folds at the nape, a single palmar crease, Brushfield spots and a wide space between the first and second toes on the feet called a sandal toe gap. Generalized hypotonia, significant head lag, and a weak moro reflex are also commonly seen.        

Patients with Down syndrome are at increased risk for congenital heart diseases, gastrointestinal malformations, hematological disorders and hearing and vision defects. Gastrointestinal anomalies include tracheoesophageal fistulas, duodenal and anal atresia, and Hirschsprung disease.        

Infants with duodenal atresia may present with difficulty feeding and bilious emesis in the first few days after birth. To confirm the diagnosis, an abdominal X-ray should be ordered. The finding of a double bubble sign, showing a distended stomach and duodenum, as seen in this patient, is consistent with duodenal atresia.   

Option Analysis

❌ Rocker bottom feet  :
Incorrect: Rocker bottom feet are commonly seen in patients with Edward syndrome (Trisomy 18), in addition to small facies with prominent occiput, small ears, and overlapping fingers. The findings in this patient and the associated duodenal atresia are more consistent with Down syndrome (Trisomy 21). Sandal toe gap is a characteristic finding in patients with Down syndrome.  
❌ Beaked nose :
Incorrect: Beaked nose (a prominent nasal bridge) is seen in patients with Crouzon syndrome in addition to craniosynostosis, strabismus and overcrowded teeth. The findings in this patient and the associated duodenal atresia are more consistent with Down syndrome. Sandal toe gap is a characteristic in patients with Down syndrome. 
✅ Sandal toe gap :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Clenched hands :
Incorrect: Clenched hands are seen in patients with Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13) in addition to microcephaly, microphthalmia, and cutis aplasia. The findings in this patient and associated duodenal atresia are more consistent with Down syndrome. 
❌ Cleft palate  :
Incorrect: Cleft palate can be seen in patients with Digeorge syndrome (22Q11 deletion) in addition to a long face, broad nose, and small jaw (micrognathia). The findings in this patient and associated duodenal atresia are more consistent with Down syndrome.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl with Down syndrome is brought to the clinic by her parent who noticed that she has had abnormal gait for one week. Her parents also report new onset urinary incontinence. She has no history of trauma, fever, headache, abnormal movements, or focal neurological symptoms. She has a past medical history of bronchial asthma that is well controlled with bronchodilators, and immunizations are up-to-date. Temperature is 37�C (98.6�F), pulse is 98/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 99/60 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On physical exam, ataxic gait is noted with increased muscle tone and increased deep tendon reflexes in the extremities. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This 9-year-old girl with Down syndrome presents with abnormal gait and urinary incontinence, which are signs of atlantoaxial instability. Patients with down syndrome are at increased risk for atlantoaxial dislocation. The best next step in management is to obtain a cervical spine X-ray to confirm the diagnosis.   

Atlantoaxial dislocation is instability between the atlas and axis (C1-C2), which results in abnormal articulation. In patients with Down syndrome, the ligamentous laxity between the C1 atlas and C2 axis cervical vertebrae, low muscle tone, and excessive joint flexibility increases the risk of spinal cord injury during cervical spine hyperextension or hyperflexion. For this reason, they should avoid activities that increase the risk of spinal cord injury, like contact sports and trampolines. Patients with Down syndrome need anesthesia or surgery and should be cleared first by a neurosurgeon.    

Down syndrome patients with atlantoaxial instability may present with new onset neck pain, weakness, spasticity or change in tone, abnormal gait, hyperreflexia, change in bowel or bladder function, or signs or symptoms of myelopathy. To evaluate, a cervical spine X-ray should be ordered to assess the atlas and axis. Dislocation of the atlas relative to the dens of the axis confirms atlantoaxial instability.   

Option Analysis

❌ Complete blood count (CBC):
Incorrect: CBC can screen for iron deficiency anemia and leukemia in patients with Down syndrome given the increased risk in these patients. The patient in this vignette has signs and symptoms of ataxia and urinary incontinence consistent with atlantoaxial instability and the best next step is to obtain a cervical spine x-ray.  
❌ Sleep study:
Incorrect: Sleep studies are commonly used to determine the etiology of sleep disorders in patients with Down syndrome who have snoring, restlessness, and daytime sleepiness, since they are at increased risk. A sleep study is not warranted in this patient who has no sleep-related complaints. Instead, a cervical spine x-ray should be performed given the signs of atlantoaxial instability. 
✅ Cervical spine X-ray:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Neurosurgery consult :
Incorrect: Consulting neurosurgery is appropriate for management in patients with atlantoaxial instability. However, the diagnosis should first be confirmed with a cervical spine X-ray.  
❌ 1 month follow-up visit :
Incorrect: This patient with Down syndrome has signs of atlantoaxial instability, and surgical correction may be required. Therefore, the diagnosis should be confirmed with cervical spine x-ray. Observation and follow-up are not appropriate in this case.

questions.text: A 24-month-old boy is brought to the clinic for a well child visit. The parents report he is unsteady while walking and trips frequently. He is unable to run and prefers to crawl up and down stairs. He knows about 20 individual words that he uses singly without stringing words together; he can only occasionally point in books at words that are said by his parents; and he can stack three blocks together. He does not help with dressing himself. Birth and past medical histories are unremarkable. Family history is pertinent for an uncle who had delayed development. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 ºF), pulse is 114/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 96/50 mm Hg and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On examination, the patient does not want to separate from his parents and tries to get attention by pointing to his cup. Neurological exams are normal. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are normal. Genetic testing shows mutations in the FMR1 gene. Which of the following physical exam findings would be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Reproduced from: Wikimedia commons . Licensed CC BY-SA 4.0 

The patient exhibits global developmental delays in language and speech, social-emotional, and motor skills with positive genetic screening for fragile X syndrome. Fragile X syndrome is the most common inherited cause of global developmental delay. Patients often have characteristic physical features, including a long narrow face and large protruding ears.

Global developmental delay is present when there are delays in two or more of the major categories of development (motor, language/speech, cognitive and social/emotional).

When assessing pediatric developmental milestones, the first step is obtaining a focused history and physical exam. Understanding normal developmental milestones based on age can help physicians and caregivers recognize when a child is at risk for developmental delay and would benefit from detailed evaluation and early intervention. Reviewing birth history is important since both prematurity and low birth weight are associated with developmental delays. Interval history is useful to determine new skills learned or if there is any regression in development. Family history can reveal genetic causes of developmental delay. Genetic conditions associated with developmental delays include fragile X syndrome, Down syndrome (trisomy 21), tuberous sclerosis, neurofibromatosis, and autism spectrum disorder.

When performing the physical exam, reflexes, muscle tone, and balance should be checked. The child's behavior and social interactions should be observed. Patients with fragile X syndrome can exhibit autistic behaviors, symptoms of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, aggression, and poor eye contact. Patients with developmental delays should also be assessed for characteristic physical features.  Physical features associated with fragile X syndrome include a long, narrow face, prominent jaw, and forehead, hyperflexible fingers, and large protruding ears.

Option Analysis

❌ Organomegaly :
Incorrect: Organomegaly may indicate glycogen storage diseases, sphingolipidoses, or mucopolysaccharidoses, which are commonly associated with motor delays. However, this patient has global developmental delay with genetic testing confirming fragile X syndrome.
❌ Spastic lower extremities:
Incorrect: Spastic lower extremities are a common feature of cerebral palsy which also presents with global developmental delays, in addition to hypertonia. This patient’s presentation lacks risk factors for cerebral palsy, such as hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, central nervous system infections, or kernicterus, and genetic testing confirms fragile X syndrome.
✅ Large protruding ears:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Calf hypertrophy:
Incorrect: Calf hypertrophy is typically a feature of Duchenne muscular dystrophy, which is characterized by progressive weakness and hypotonia. This patient’s physical exam, global developmental delay, and genetic testing are consistent with fragile X syndrome.
❌ Cleft palate:
Incorrect: Cleft palate is a common feature of DiGeorge syndrome, which is associated with hypotonia, delayed development, and congenital heart defects. This patient’s physical exam, global developmental delay, and genetic testing are consistent with fragile X syndrome.

questions.text:
A 6-hour-old newborn delivered at 39 weeks' gestation is evaluated for jitteriness. The mother had little prenatal care. Rupture of membranes was at delivery, and maternal labs were within normal limits. No fever, vomiting, or seizures are reported. Temperature is 37° C (98.6° F), pulse is 165/min, respiration is 38/min, blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Weight is 4100 grams, and length is 49 centimeters. On physical exam, the infant is jittery. The anterior fontanelle is open and flat. Macroglossia is noted; mucous membranes are moist. The newborn’s left lower limb appears larger than the right. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. Umbilical hernia is noted with no organomegaly. Laboratory results are shown below. Which of the following is the most probable cause of this patient’s hypoglycemia?

 Laboratory value Results
 Blood glucose 35 mg/dL
 Serum bicarbonate 21 meq/L
 Insulin High
 C-peptide High
 Free fatty acids Low
 Betahydroxybutyrate Low
 Urine reducing substances Negative
questions.solution:
This infant has macrosomia, macroglossia, an umbilical hernia, and hemihypertrophy. These findings are consistent with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome (BWS) which is associated with hypoglycemia secondary to hyperinsulinism.

Hyperinsulinism is the most common cause of hypoglycemia during infancy. Hyperinsulinism can be classified as transient or persistent. Transient physiologic hyperinsulinism occurs in infants who are small or large for gestational age, preterm, or infants of a diabetic mother and is seen in the first two days of life. Hyperinsulinemic hypoglycemia can also be caused by ingestion of medications such as insulin or sulfonylureas.

Hyperinsulinism can also be a feature of some genetic syndromes, including Beckwith-Widemann syndrome (BWS), which is a congenital overgrowth syndrome caused by a mutation in chromosome 11p15. Patients with BWS can have transient or persistent hypoglycemia. Persistent hypoglycemia is due to islet cell hyperplasia and congenital hyperinsulinism. Other features of BWS are macrosomia, limb-length discrepancy, hemihypertrophy, abdominal wall defects (omphalocele, umbilical hernia), and organomegaly. Typical dysmorphic facies include macroglossia, prominent eyes, infraorbital creases, anterior earlobe creases, posterior helical pits, and facial nevus flammeus.

Laboratory findings seen in patients with hyperinsulinism include elevated insulin and C-peptide levels, decreased free fatty acids, and decreased beta-hydroxybutyrate. Another diagnostic test for hyperinsulinism is an increase in plasma glucose levels of more than 30 mg/dL in response to glucagon administration during hypoglycemia. The finding of high plasma insulin levels in the setting of undetectable C-peptide would suggest exogenous insulin administration.

Option Analysis

✅ Hyperinsulinism  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hypopituitarism  :
Incorrect: Patients with hypopituitarism typically present with midline defects, such as cleft lip and palate, cholestatic jaundice, microphallus, and hypoglycemia. This patient’s macrosomia, macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, and umbilical hernia are consistent with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome which is associated with hypoglycemia secondary to hyperinsulinism.
❌ Fatty acid oxidation defect  :
Incorrect: Infants with fatty acid oxidation defects have hypoglycemia with hypoketosis and elevated free fatty acids, which are not noted in this patient. This patient’s macrosomia, macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, and umbilical hernia are consistent with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome which is associated with hypoglycemia secondary to hyperinsulinism.
❌ Inborn error of carbohydrate metabolism:
Incorrect: Infants with inborn errors of carbohydrate metabolism such as galactosemia and hereditary fructose intolerance present with postprandial hypoglycemia and positive urine non-glucose reducing substances, which are not noted in this patient.
❌ Idiopathic ketotic hypoglycemic disorder:
Incorrect: Patients with ketotic hypoglycemic disorders have hypoglycemia with acidosis and ketosis, which are not noted in this patient. This patient’s macrosomia, macroglossia, hemihypertrophy, and umbilical hernia are consistent with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome which is associated with hypoglycemia secondary to hyperinsulinism.

questions.text: A 3-day-old newborn boy is evaluated in the hospital for poor feeding. The parents reports that the infant has had trouble swallowing during feeds and occasional episodes of “shortness of breath” with a high-pitched inspiratory sound. The infant was born at 36 weeks’ gestation via vaginal delivery without complications. The prenatal course was otherwise unremarkable. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate is 150/min, blood pressure is 85/40 mmHg, respiratory rate is 40/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals normal tone and reflexes with intermittent stridor. Gene sequencing confirms a diagnosis of Pierre Robin sequence. Which of the following additional findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

choices.text: Retained fluid in the nasal cavity
Defect in the soft or hard palate

questions.solution:
This 3-day-old newborn presents with poor feeding, stridor, and a diagnosis of Pierre Robin sequence, a rare congenital condition characterized by a combination of facial anomalies that typically present at birth, including micrognathia. Micrognathia, or an underdeveloped lower jaw, can impair feeding. Glossoptosis, the backward displacement of the tongue, can lead to airway obstruction and stridor.         

In an infant with poor feeding, the history and physical examination often reveal characteristic findings. Caregivers may report difficulty with latching or swallowing, or signs of respiratory distress such as stridor, stertor, or frequent coughing. Physical examination may show craniofacial abnormalities including cleft palate or micrognathia. In the absence of these features, frothing and bubbling at the nose and mouth may suggest esophageal atresia, while cyanosis that improves with crying, or inspiratory stridor during feeding or crying, may indicate choanal atresia or laryngomalacia, respectively. Ankyloglossia typically presents with latching difficulty and a tight lingual or upper lip frenulum.   

Option Analysis

❌ Collapse of supraglottic structures :
Incorrect: This finding is commonly associated with laryngomalacia, which may present with stridor but is not associated with Pierre Robin sequence. 
❌ Retained fluid in the nasal cavity :
Incorrect: Retained nasal fluid with respiratory distress is more suggestive of choanal atresia, which typically presents with difficulty breathing through the nose and cyanosis that improves with crying. This patient has normal oxygen saturation and no signs of nasal blockage. 
❌ Tight upper lip frenulum :
Incorrect: A tight upper lip frenulum may cause difficulty with latching, but it does not cause stridor or impaired swallowing. These features suggest a more significant structural anomaly affecting the airway and feeding coordination. 
✅ Undersized mandible and overbite :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Defect in the soft or hard palate :
Incorrect: A cleft palate may be present in Pierre Robin sequence and can contribute to feeding difficulties. However, it does not typically cause stridor or signs of airway obstruction. These features suggest glossoptosis, which results from mandibular hypoplasia.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic due to concerns regarding the lack of facial hair and pubic hair. There is no history of seizures, headaches, or exposure to radiation. Family history and birth history are unremarkable. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 115/75 mm Hg. On physical examination, the patient has no facial hair, no pubic hair, and small testes. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are normal. Luteinizing hormones, follicle stimulating hormones and testosterone levels are low. Genetic testing is positive for ANOS1 gene mutation. Which of the following additional findings would be expected?

choices.text: Elevated TSH and low free T4

questions.solution:
This 15-year-old boy who presents with delayed puberty is found to have hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and a positive ANOS1 gene mutation confirming the diagnosis of Kallman syndrome. Anosmia (i.e., impaired, or absent sense of smell) is a characteristic clinical feature of Kallman syndrome.

Kallman syndrome is an inherited disorder with a genetic mutation of anosmin-1 (ANOS1) formerly called the (KAL1) gene. Patients with Kallman syndrome can have a combination of delayed puberty, anosmia, and midline defects, such as a cleft lip or palate and gonadotropins deficiency. Patients may also have color blindness, atrial septal defects, and renal structural anomalies. Some patients present with bimanual synkinesia, also known as mirror movement, where voluntary movement of one hand results in involuntary movement of the other hand.

Physical examination may show lack of hair and small testes. Patients will have low levels of luteinizing hormone, follicle-stimulating hormone, and testosterone, indicating congenital hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Left-hand X-ray should be obtained and may reveal delayed bone age. A scratch-and-sniff smell test should be ordered to test for anosmia when Kallman syndrome is suspected. Genetic testing can confirm the diagnosis with presence of ANOS1 (KAL1) gene mutation.

Option Analysis

✅ Anosmia  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Gynecomastia  :
Incorrect: Gynecomastia may be found in male patients with hyperprolactinemia who have delayed puberty. This patient’s findings of delayed puberty and prepubertal levels on bloodwork are consistent with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This patient is positive for the ANOS1 gene mutation consistent with the anosmic form of Isolated gonadotropin-releasing hormone deficiency (i.e., Kallman syndrome). Anosmia would be expected. 
❌ Visual field defects :
Incorrect: Visual field defects and headaches are typically noted in patients with central nervous system tumors compressing the pituitary gland or the hypothalamus which can lead to acquired hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. This patient with delayed puberty and ANOS1 gene mutation has Kallman syndrome and therefore anosmia would be expected. 
❌ Excessive exercising:
Incorrect: Functional hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is when there is impairment of the hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis (HPG-A) functioning, resulting in decreased testosterone and delayed puberty. Excessive exercise can cause this. However, this patient has the genetic mutation associated with Kallman syndrome, which is the cause of delayed puberty, and amsonia would be expected. 
❌ Elevated TSH and low free T4:
Incorrect: Severe primary hypothyroidism can cause these lab results and delayed puberty. However, this patient has the genetic mutation associated with Kallman syndrome, which is the cause of delayed puberty, and amsonia would be expected.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for frequent joint dislocations over the summer break. The patient has not had frequent fractures, joint pain, vision problems, headaches, or fever. Family history reveals that the paternal grandfather had extremely flexible joints. There is no significant past medical or surgical history, and the child does not take any medication. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 115/76 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Height and weight are at the 35th percentile for age. On physical exam, multiple bruises and scars are seen over both lower legs and knees. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. Which of the following additional physical exam findings is most likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Increased arm span to height ratio

questions.solution:
Hypermobile joints and skin hyperelasticity in Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.
Reproduced from Wikipedia and Wikipedia . Licensed under CC by 2.5 and CC BY-SA 4.0  
This 10-year-old child's history and presentation are most consistent with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS), as evidenced by frequent joint dislocations, a family history of hypermobile joints, and physical exam findings of normal height, bruising, and scarring of the skin. Hyperextensible skin is an additional feature expected in patients with EDS.

Children with connective tissue disorders often present with chronic joint pain, recurrent joint dislocations, fractures, fragile skin, and/or poor wound healing. Many will also have ophthalmologic manifestations, such as severe myopia. A family history may reveal a first- or second-degree relative with a connective tissue disorder.

Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS) is a spectrum of heritable conditions caused by collagen defects. Classic EDS and hypermobility EDS are the most common types. Children with EDS typically experience chronic joint pain, frequent joint dislocations, or subluxations, and may have delayed motor milestones, such as walking. They may also have fragile skin that bruises and tears easily, with poor healing. Characteristic physical exam findings include hypermobile joints; thin, velvety, hyperextensible skin; wide atrophic scars; and striae. Hypotonia can be noted. A heart murmur and mid-systolic click can be auscultated if the patient has mitral valve prolapse.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Arachnodactyly:
Incorrect: Arachnodactyly is typically seen in patients with Marfan syndrome, commonly associated with tall stature, long extremities, and ectopia lentis. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is associated with hyperextensible skin.
❌ Blue sclera:
Incorrect: Blue sclera is usually seen in patients with osteogenesis imperfecta, in addition to frequent low-impact fractures and short stature. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is associated with hyperextensible skin.
✅ Hyperextensible skin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Light skin and hair:
Incorrect: Light skin and hair may be seen in patients with phenylketonuria, in addition to eczema and a musty odor from the skin and urine. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is associated with hyperextensible skin.
❌ Increased arm span to height ratio:
Incorrect: Increased arm span to height ratio is seen in patients with Marfan syndrome, commonly associated with arachnodactyly, tall stature, and ectopia lentis. The findings in this patient are more consistent with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, which is associated with hyperextensible skin.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the clinic for delayed development. The caregivers report the child has not started walking, is unable to climb on or off furniture, and does not follow one-step directions. There is no history of characteristic odors, meningitis, or stroke. The caregivers report a past medical history of pulmonary embolism. The infant was born at home, and the family moved to the United States when he was 6 months of age. All immunizations are up to date. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 90/46 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Height is at the 95<sup>th</sup> percentile for age, and weight is at the 45<sup>th</sup> percentile. On examination, the infant appears fair-skinned and blue-eyed, with no abnormal facial features. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Laboratory studies show elevated urine homocysteine levels. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Fragile X messenger ribonucleoprotein 1 (FMR1) gene mutation

questions.solution:
The findings described in this 18-month-old infant are most consistent with homocystinuria. The infant presents with global developmental delay, a history of a thrombotic event, fair skin, marfanoid habitus, and elevated urine homocysteine levels. Homocystinuria is caused by a cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) genetic mutation.

In connective tissue disorders, growth patterns can help narrow the differential diagnosis. Disorders associated with excessive long bone growth, such as Marfan syndrome and homocystinuria, may present with taller stature. However, this difference in height may not be apparent in infancy and often becomes more noticeable as the child grows.

Homocystinuria is an autosomal recessive inborn error of metabolism caused by cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) enzyme deficiency. This results in elevated homocysteine levels which interfere with collagen and fibrillin formation, leading to connective tissue dysfunction. Children with homocystinuria often experience developmental delays and progressive intellectual impairment. They may also present with downward lens subluxation, marfanoid body habitus, and hypercoagulability, which can result in pulmonary embolism or stroke. Examination findings include a tall, thin frame, long limbs, chest wall deformities, and scoliosis.

Laboratory testing typically reveals elevated plasma levels of methionine and homocysteine, with low levels of cysteine. Elevated levels of urinary homocysteine are diagnostic. Genetic testing will demonstrate a mutation in the CBS gene, confirming the diagnosis.

Option Analysis

❌ Fragile X messenger ribonucleoprotein 1 (FMR1) gene mutation:
Incorrect: Fragile X syndrome is caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene and typically presents with tall stature, developmental delays, and characteristic facial features such as large ears and an elongated face. This patient's findings are more consistent with homocystinuria, caused by a mutation in the cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) gene.
❌ Collagen-1 gene mutation:
Incorrect: Osteogenesis imperfecta is caused by a mutation in the collagen-1 gene and typically presents with frequent fractures and blue sclerae. This patient's findings are more consistent with homocystinuria, caused by a mutation in the cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) gene.
❌ Collagen-5 gene mutation:
Incorrect: Ehlers-Danlos syndrome is caused by a mutation in the collagen-5 gene and typically presents with joint hypermobility and hyperextensible skin. This patient's findings are more consistent with homocystinuria, caused by a mutation in the cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) gene.
✅ Cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) gene mutation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fibrilin-1 gene mutation:
Incorrect: Marfan syndrome is caused by mutations in the fibrillin-1 gene and typically presents with chronic joint pain, arachnodactyly, mitral valve prolapse, and aortic root dilation. This patient's findings are more consistent with homocystinuria, caused by a mutation in the cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS) gene.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is transported by emergency medical services to the emergency department for sudden onset of severe chest pain radiating to the lower back. The patient has not experienced recent illnesses, cough, dyspnea, orthopnea, fever, night sweats, or chest trauma. There is no significant past medical or surgical history, and the patient takes no medication. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 135/86 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination reveals tall stature and arachnodactyly. No lymphadenopathy or edema is noted. Cardiac examination reveals a mid-systolic click. Pulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Chest X-ray shows a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This adolescent boy presents with severe chest pain radiating to the back, along with physical examination findings of tachycardia, hypertension, a marfanoid body habitus, and arachnodactyly. Chest X-ray shows a widened mediastinum. These findings are most consistent with aortic dissection secondary to Marfan syndrome.

Marfan syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations of the fibrillin-1 (FBN1) gene. Patients often experience chronic joint pain, and some may develop ectopia lentis (dislocation of the optic lens), which can cause ocular pain, myopia, and diplopia. Physical examination typically reveals a tall, thin frame with an increased arm span-to-height ratio. Other common findings include arachnodactyly, pectus carinatum, pectus excavatum, and scoliosis. A heart murmur with a mid-systolic click is consistent with mitral valve prolapse, a condition frequently seen in patients with Marfan syndrome.
   
Marfanoid body habitus. Reproduced from: Wikipedia. Licensed under CC BY 2.0 
Marfan syndrome leads to weakness of the aortic wall, leading to progressive aortic root dilatation and increased risk of aortic dissection. The classic presentation involves sudden, severe pain in the anterior chest that radiates to the back. However, patients may also present with stroke-like symptoms, limb weakness, or paresthesias. Electrocardiogram (ECG) findings are often nonspecific, and chest X-ray may reveal a widened mediastinum and an abnormal aortic contour. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) is the diagnostic tool of choice for aortic dissection, although transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) can be used in hemodynamically unstable patients or when CTA is unavailable.

Option Analysis

✅ Aortic dissection:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Heart failure:
Incorrect: Patients with heart failure typically present with dyspnea, orthopnea, and edema. Chest X-rays more commonly show signs of pulmonary edema, rather than a widened mediastinum. The physical exam findings in this case, including tall stature, arachnodactyly, and mitral valve prolapse, should raise suspicion for Marfan syndrome, which is a significant risk factor for aortic dissection.
❌ Hodgkin lymphoma:
Incorrect: Patients with Hodgkin lymphoma usually present with lymphadenopathy, fever, and night sweats. Chest X-ray may show a widened mediastinum. However, the physical exam findings in this case, including tall stature, arachnodactyly, and mitral valve prolapse, should raise suspicion for Marfan syndrome, which is a significant risk factor for aortic dissection.
❌ Mediastinal teratoma:
Incorrect: Mediastinal teratomas are rare benign germ cell tumors that present with cough, dyspnea, dysphagia, and chest discomfort. Chest X-ray may show a widened mediastinum. However, the physical exam findings in this case, including tall stature, arachnodactyly, and mitral valve prolapse, should raise suspicion for Marfan syndrome, which is a significant risk factor for aortic dissection.
❌ Thymoma:
Incorrect: Patients with a thymoma present with chest pain, cough, stridor, and dysphagia, and chest X-ray may show a widened mediastinum. However, the physical exam findings in this case, including tall stature, arachnodactyly, and mitral valve prolapse, should raise suspicion for Marfan syndrome, which is a significant risk factor for aortic dissection.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician's office for evaluation of rapid weight gain and excessive appetite. A caregiver reports that the child had difficulty feeding at birth due to poor sucking. Developmental milestones, particularly motor skills, have been delayed compared to siblings. Pregnancy was uncomplicated. Immunizations are up to date. Family history is non-contributory. Temperature is 37° C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Weight is at the 97th percentile for age. Physical examination reveals almond-shaped eyes, a thin upper lip, and micropenis. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Which of the following studies should be obtained to confirm the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Characteristic facial features, truncal obesity, and small hands and feet associated with Prader-Willi syndrome. Reproduced from; Wikipedia      Licensed under: CC BY 2.0  

This child has Prader-Willi syndrome. The clinical history of feeding difficulties as a neonate, developmental motor delays, insatiable appetite, and characteristic facial features support this diagnosis. Genetic testing should be obtained for confirmation.       

The differential diagnosis for hypotonia can be broadly categorized into central and peripheral nervous system etiologies. In pediatric patients with developmental delays or seizures, central causes such as inborn errors of metabolism, hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy, and structural brain or spinal cord abnormalities should be considered. Evaluation should include a careful physical examination for syndromic features, followed by brain imaging, metabolic studies, EEG, and genetic testing when appropriate.       
Infants with Prader-Willi syndrome typically present with hypotonia and poor feeding. As they grow, affected children typically develop hyperphagia that can lead to obesity, along with hypogonadism, developmental delays, and behavioral issues, including obsessive-compulsive traits. Distinctive physical findings may include almond-shaped eyes, a thin upper lip, small hands and feet, micropenis and cryptorchidism in males, or clitoral and labial hypoplasia in females. The diagnosis is confirmed with genetic testing, most commonly identifying a deletion in chromosome 15q11–q13.   

Option Analysis

❌ Creatinine kinase (CK) levels:
Incorrect: CK is typically elevated in muscular dystrophies and other primary myopathies. This patient presents with a history of early feeding problems and delayed motor skills, current hyperphagia, and characteristic facial features, which suggests Prader-Willi syndrome. Genetic testing should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis.  
❌ Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis  :
Incorrect: Elevated protein and a normal white blood cell count on CSF analysis supports a diagnosis of Gulian-Barré syndrome, which presents with hypotonia and ascending paralysis, often after a viral infection. However, this patient presents with a history of early feeding problems and delayed motor skills, current hyperphagia, and characteristic facial features, which suggests Prader-Willi syndrome. Genetic testing should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis. 
✅ Genetic testing  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Metabolic screening :
Incorrect: Metabolic screening may be useful in identifying inborn errors of metabolism, which can present with hypotonia and developmental delay. However, the presence of dysmorphic features and hyperphagia makes Prader-Willi syndrome more likely. Genetic testing should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Muscle biopsy  :
Incorrect: Muscle biopsy is useful in the diagnosis of muscular diseases. However, this patient presents with a history of early feeding problems and delayed motor skills, current hyperphagia, and characteristic facial features, which suggests Prader-Willi syndrome. Genetic testing should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy presents to the clinic along with a parent for evaluation of gross hematuria for 3 weeks. Medical history is notable for visual impairment and an incidental finding of microscopic hematuria on previous urinalysis. There is no history of vomiting, diarrhea, or skin rash. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 75/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Edema is noted in bilateral lower extremities. Ophthalmologic examination reveals anterior lenticonus. Renal biopsy shows a “basket-weave” appearance of the glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy (EM). Which of the following is most likely to be found on further questioning?
questions.solution:
This adolescent has Alport syndrome. This hereditary disorder commonly presents with hematuria, hypertension, edema, and ocular abnormalities such as anterior lenticonus. Visual impairment may be noted early, and sensorineural hearing loss often develops during childhood or adolescence. Renal biopsy typically reveals glomerular basement membrane (GBM) splitting and a “basket-weave” appearance on electron microscopy. A family history of deafness or renal failure is frequently present.        

Nephritic syndrome typically presents with gross hematuria that may appear frankly bloody, cola-colored, or tea-colored, along with decreased urine output. Physical examination often reveals elevated blood pressure and edema. Urinalysis shows hematuria with or without proteinuria, and microscopy reveals red blood cells and red blood cell casts. A preceding upper respiratory infection may suggest post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis or IgA nephropathy, depending on timing and clinical context.       

In the absence of an infection history, additional clinical features can help narrow the differential diagnosis. Alport syndrome is associated with sensorineural hearing loss, ocular abnormalities involving the cornea, lens, and retina, and a family history of renal failure and/or deafness. Pulmonary symptoms such as cough, sinus congestion, or hemoptysis may suggest pulmonary-renal syndrome, including anti-GBM disease or ANCA-associated vasculitis. A history of chronic systemic illness, such as hepatitis B or systemic lupus erythematosus, may also indicate an alternative etiology.   

Option Analysis

❌ Recent streptococcal pharyngitis infection :
Incorrect: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis typically presents 1 to 3 weeks after pharyngitis with acute onset of hematuria, edema, and hypertension. However, it is not associated with chronic microscopic hematuria, ocular abnormalities such as anterior lenticonus, or the “basket-weave” appearance of the glomerular basement membrane on EM, which are more characteristic of Alport syndrome. 
❌ Malar rash  :
Incorrect: A malar rash is characteristic of systemic lupus erythematosus, which may cause lupus nephritis. However, lupus nephritis typically also presents with systemic symptoms such as fatigue, joint pain, and photosensitivity. This patient lacks those features, and the presence of visual impairment and a “basket-weave” appearance of the glomerular basement membrane on EM are characteristic of Alport syndrome. 
✅ Family history for deafness :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hemoptysis:
Incorrect: Hemoptysis is seen in pulmonary-renal syndromes such as anti-GBM disease or ANCA-associated vasculitis. They do not typically cause anterior lenticonus or a “basket-weave” appearance of the glomerular basement membrane on EM. 
❌ Hepatitis B infection :
Incorrect: Hepatitis B virus can be associated with membranous nephropathy or membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, particularly in children. However, these conditions do not typically present with ocular findings such as anterior lenticonus or a “basket-weave” appearance of the glomerular basement membrane on electron microscopy. This patient’s combination of renal, ocular, and biopsy findings is characteristic of Alport syndrome.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents to the clinic for gynecomastia that has been present for three months. There is no history of medication use, oil use, recent infection, or travel. Parents report learning difficulties at school. Birth and family history are non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 15/min, blood pressure is 119/68 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Weight is at the 45<sup>th</sup> percentile and height is at the 99<sup>th</sup> percentile for age. Physical examination reveals bilateral gynecomastia, pubic hair at Tanner stage 2, and small firm testes bilaterally. Which of the following is expected on karyotype analysis?
questions.solution:
This adolescent patient exhibits features consistent with Klinefelter syndrome, including gynecomastia, developmental delay, tall stature, small firm testicles, and lack of secondary sexual characteristics. A chromosome analysis showing 47,XXY would confirm the diagnosis.

Chromosomal microarray analysis (CMA) and fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) should be ordered for patients with concerns for aneuploidy or microdeletion. Conditions characterized by aneuploidy include trisomy 13, 18, and 21, which present in the neonatal period, as well as Turner or Klinefelter syndromes, which present in childhood or adolescence.

Symptoms of Klinefelter syndrome become evident at puberty. If a pediatric patient is phenotypically male and has tall stature, Klinefelter syndrome should be considered. This contrasts with Turner syndrome, where patients are phenotypically female with short stature. Klinefelter syndrome is also associated with delayed puberty, learning disabilities, language and processing deficits, and psychiatric conditions such as ADHD or depression. On physical exam, long limbs, a lack of secondary sexual characteristics, gynecomastia, and small firm testes are often observed. Gonadotropins (FSH and LH) are usually elevated, while testosterone levels are low. A definitive diagnosis is made through karyotype analysis or chromosomal microarray testing. A finding of 47,XXY confirms the diagnosis.

Option Analysis

❌ 47,XX,+21:
Incorrect: The karyotype 47,XX,+21 is consistent with Down syndrome. This condition presents with hypotonia, brachycephaly, a single palmar crease, wide-spaced toes, and upward-slanting palpebral fissures. However, the clinical presentation in this case is more consistent with Klinefelter syndrome, which is associated with a 47,XXY karyotype.
❌ 45,XO:
Incorrect: The karyotype 45,XO is consistent with Turner syndrome, which occurs in phenotypical females and presents with lymphedema, a short, webbed neck, widely-spaced nipples, and congenital heart defects. The clinical presentation in this case is more consistent with Klinefelter syndrome, which is associated with a 47,XXY karyotype.
✅ 47,XXY:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 47,XX,+18:
Incorrect: The karyotype 47,XX,+18 is consistent with Edwards syndrome, which typically presents within the first two years of life with poor growth, cardiac anomalies, microcephaly, cleft lip and/or palate, micrognathia, low-set or malformed ears, clenched fists, and rocker-bottom feet. However, the clinical presentation in this case is more consistent with Klinefelter syndrome, which is associated with a 47,XXY karyotype.
❌ 47,XX,+13:
Incorrect: The karyotype 47,XX,+13 is consistent with Patau syndrome, which typically presents within the first two years of life with poor growth, microcephaly, microphthalmia, cleft lip and palate, clinodactyly, and polydactyly. However, the clinical presentation in this case is more consistent with Klinefelter syndrome, which is associated with a 47,XXY karyotype.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy with Down syndrome is brought to the clinic for a well child visit. His parents report frequent diarrhea and bloating for one month. Symptoms worsen when the patient eats white bread and wheat products. He has no history of choking, problems sleeping, constipation, neck pain, or neurological symptoms. He has no significant past medical history. Growth charts show weight dropped from 25th percentile to 10th percentile since the last visit. Height is at the 20th percentile and head circumference is at the 25th percentile. Temperature is 37�C (98.6�F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 96/53 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical exam, the abdomen is soft, slightly distended, and non-tender. Cardiopulmonary and neurological examinations are unremarkable. There is a vesicular rash with excoriations on the back and the buttocks. Which of the following tests should be performed next to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 2-year-old boy with Down syndrome presents with new onset diarrhea and bloating after eating wheat and poor growth. His physical examination is significant for abdominal distention and dermatitis herpetiformis. The most likely diagnosis is celiac disease. Patients with Down syndrome are at increased risk for celiac disease and tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A (TTG IgA) can be used to detect celiac disease.        

Patients with Down syndrome are at increased risk for autoimmune diseases such as celiac disease, diabetes mellitus, and hypothyroidism. Celiac disease is an immune-mediated systemic disorder that results in inflammation and damage to the small intestine caused by gluten-containing food such as wheat, rye, and barley. Patients with celiac disease typically present with chronic diarrhea, growth faltering, and abdominal pain or bloating. Patients may also have extraintestinal manifestations such as dermatitis herpetiformis (itchy papulovesicular rash on buttocks, back, scalp and extremities).        

To diagnose celiac disease, TTG IgA and quantitative IgA levels should be obtained. If the TTG IgA is positive, and the quantitative IgA is normal, the patient most likely has celiac disease. An endoscopy with biopsies can confirm the diagnosis.   

Option Analysis

❌ Thyroid panel  :
Incorrect: Thyroid panel is useful for diagnosing hypothyroidism in patients with Down syndrome, which typically presents with poor growth, constipation, and dry skin. The findings in this patient are more consistent with celiac disease. Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A is the best test to detect celiac disease.  
❌ Swallow study  :
Incorrect: Swallow study is useful for determining the etiology of dysphagia in patients with Down syndrome who typically present with poor feeding, poor growth, and choking. This patient has findings consistent with celiac disease, and a swallow study would not be helpful for making the diagnosis.
✅ Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A (TTG IgA) :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Echocardiogram  :
Incorrect: Echocardiogram is commonly used to confirm congenital heart defects in patients with Down syndrome. The findings in this patient are more consistent with celiac disease, which can be detected with tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A (TTG IgA). 
❌ Complete blood count (CBC) :
Incorrect: CBC can be performed to screen patients with Down syndrome for iron deficiency and leukemia. This patient’s presentation is consistent with celiac disease, which can be detected with tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A (TTG IgA).

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presents to the pediatrician for a well-child visit. The patient has myopia but is otherwise healthy. The patient has started puberty but has not yet had menarche. She has always been small for her age; height is currently less than 3<sup>rd</sup> percentile, weight is 8<sup>th</sup> percentile, and mid-parental height is 47<sup>th</sup> percentile. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 14/min, blood pressure is 112/73 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is well-appearing. The patient’s neck is wide, and the chest is broad. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Breasts are Tanner stage 1, and pubic hair is Tanner stage 4. There is nail dysplasia and short 4<sup>th</sup> metacarpals and metatarsals. Which of the following tests would confirm the underlying cause of this patient’s short stature?

choices.text: Insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) and insulin-like growth factor binding protein 3 (IGFBP-3)
Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and free thyroxine (T4)

questions.solution:
This 13-year-old patient assigned female at birth presents to the pediatrician for a well-visit and is found to have short stature. Physical examination identifies a webbed neck, broad chest, adrenarche without thelarche, nail dysplasia, and short 4th digits. These findings are consistent with Turner syndrome. High blood pressure during the well-child visit and a history of myopia also supports this diagnosis. Turner syndrome is diagnosed by karyotype.

The first step in evaluating a patient with short stature is to identify whether the short stature is pathologic or non-pathologic. If the height velocity is normal, and there are no signs and symptoms of an underlying condition, the patient likely has non-pathologic short stature. This is confirmed with a bone age radiograph.

Lab work is typically necessary to diagnose the various pathologic causes of short stature. When weight-for-length ratio is decreased, malnutrition, chronic illness, or celiac disease may be the cause of short stature. Celiac disease is diagnosed with anti-tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A and immunoglobulin G. Chronic illness can be difficult to diagnose, but physical examination and screening labs, such as a complete blood count, complete metabolic panel, inflammatory markers, and urinalysis, can aide in making a diagnosis.

When weight-for-length ratio is normal or increased, endocrine or genetic disorders may be the cause. Endocrine disorders should be considered, including hypothyroidism and growth hormone deficiency, which can be diagnosed with thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and free thyroxine (T4) or insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) and insulin-like growth factor binding protein 3 (IGFBP-3), respectively. Idiopathic short stature is a diagnosis of exclusion; the history, physical, and laboratory studies will all be normal.

Option Analysis

✅ Karyotype:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) and insulin-like growth factor binding protein 3 (IGFBP-3):
Incorrect: IGF-1 and IGFBP-3 are growth hormones, and low levels of these hormones signify growth hormone deficiency. This patient most likely has Turner syndrome, which can be diagnosed by karyotype. Although patients with Turner syndrome often require growth hormone, they don’t usually have a true growth hormone deficiency.
❌ Bone age radiograph:
Incorrect: A bone age radiograph is used to evaluate for constitutional growth delay, which is a non-pathological cause of short stature. This patient’s physical examination findings, including a webbed neck, wide chest, and nail dysplasia, are consistent with Turner syndrome. This genetic cause of short stature can be diagnosed by karyotype.
❌ Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and free thyroxine (T4) :
Incorrect: TSH and free T4 are used to evaluate for abnormal thyroid function. Although hypothyroidism can cause short stature, this patient’s physical examination findings, including a webbed neck, wide chest, and nail dysplasia, are more consistent with Turner syndrome, which can be diagnosed by karyotype.
❌ Pelvic ultrasound :
Incorrect: This patient’s physical examination, including short stature, delay in thelarche, webbed neck, wide chest, and nail dysplasia, is concerning for Turner syndrome. In patients with Turner syndrome, a pelvic ultrasound may diagnose streak ovaries, which are associated with Turner syndrome. However, a karyotype provides definitive diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 12-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department for lethargy. While in the emergency department, the infant develops generalized seizures. The family has moved a lot recently, and the patient has not seen a pediatrician in over six months. There is no history of fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. Past medical and surgical histories are unremarkable. The patient was born full-term without complications. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 87/45 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Weight and height are at the 3rd percentile for age. On physical exam, the infant is lethargic with moist mucous membranes. The anterior fontanelle is small but open and flat. The abdomen is soft and nontender, but it is distended, and hepatomegaly is noted. The cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. The patient’s point-of-care glucose in the emergency department is 25 mg/dL. The infant is stabilized and admitted. Laboratory studies are obtained, and a chart review reveals genetic testing. The results can be seen below. Which of the following additional physical exam findings would be expected in this patient?

Laboratory valueResults 
Serum bicarbonate15 mEq/L
Serum lactate6 mmol/L (normal < 2.4mmol/L)
Genetic testingGlucose-6-Phosphatase Catalytic (G6PC) gene mutation
questions.solution:
This infant presents with lethargy and develops seizures in the emergency department. There is failure to thrive and hepatomegaly on physical exam. Laboratory results show hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and a positive Glucose-6-Phosphatase Catalytic Subunit (G6PC) gene mutation consistent with glycogen storage disease type I (GSD I). Doll-like facies are a characteristic feature of GSD I.  

Glycogen storage disease type I (GSD I, or von Gierke disease) is caused by a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase, which can impair glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis. Patients with GSD I present with hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and hypoketosis usually 2–4 hours after a meal. Hepatomegaly and doll-like facies are typically seen on physical exams. Labs may also reveal hyperlipidemia and hyperuricemia. If genetic testing reveals a mutation in the G6PC gene, GSD I can be diagnosed. In patients with hypoglycemia, metabolic acidosis, and ketosis, glycogen storage disease types 0, III, VI, and IX should be considered.

Option Analysis

❌ Hemihypertrophy  :
Incorrect: Hemihypertrophy, in addition to somatic gigantism, macroglossia, omphalocele, and hypoglycemia without metabolic acidosis, is seen in patients with Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. This patient's genetic testing confirms Glycogen Storage Disease Type I, which is associated with doll-like facies.
❌ Microphallus  :
Incorrect: Microphallus, in addition to midline defects, poor growth, cholestatic jaundice, and hypoglycemia without metabolic acidosis, is seen with congenital hypopituitarism. This patient has Glycogen Storage Disease Type I, confirmed by genetic testing, which is associated with doll-like facies.
✅ Doll-like facies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Skin hyperpigmentation:
Incorrect: Skin and mucosal hyperpigmentation, in addition to hypoglycemia and metabolic acidosis, are seen in patients with primary adrenal insufficiency. This patient has Glycogen Storage Disease Type I, confirmed by genetic testing, which is associated with doll-like facies.
❌ Heart murmur:
Incorrect: Glycogen Storage Disease IIb is associated with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, and a murmur would be auscultated; however, this patient has Glycogen Storage Disease Type I (GSDI), confirmed by genetic testing.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. There is no history of headache, lethargy, vomiting, fever, rash, or previous seizures. Developmental milestones are delayed. The patient has a history of multiple prior admissions for pneumonia. Birth and family history are non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 25/min, blood pressure is 92/46 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Flexion of the wrist and thumb with the extension of the fingers is noted with application of the sphygmomanometer. Physical examination reveals coarse facial features with a long face, small ears, and decreased ear creases. The patient’s voice sounds hypernasal. No neck stiffness is noted, and neurological exam is unremarkable. Laboratory studies are pending. Which of the following is the best next step in management following seizure control?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain

questions.solution:
The patient with a history of developmental delays, recurrent infections, and abnormal facies presents with seizures. There is a positive Trousseau sign (flexion of the wrist and thumb with the extension of the fingers with application of the sphygmomanometer), which suggests hypocalcemia, most likely secondary to DiGeorge syndrome. The best next step in management is to obtain a serum calcium level and administer emergent intravenous (IV) calcium gluconate.

Patients with aneuploidies and microdeletions may develop critical illness and require acute management, making recognition paramount. In a patient presenting with seizures and characteristic facial features including hypertelorism, cleft lip and palate, and micrognathia, consider velocardiofacial/DiGeorge syndrome. Affected patients often exhibit the CHARGE association, which includes coloboma, heart defects, choanal atresia, restricted growth, genital abnormalities, and ear abnormalities. Some may also have a small or absent thymus, immunodeficiency, speech and language difficulties, and hypocalcemia-induced seizures. The exam often reveals a long face and a prominent nose with a broad root. If the chromosomal analysis shows a deletion on the long arm of chromosome 22 (22q11.2), velocardiofacial/DiGeorge syndrome can be diagnosed.

In a patient presenting with generalized tonic-clonic seizures, an ABCDE assessment should be performed. If the patient appears unstable, the first step is to stabilize the airway, breathing, and circulation. Continuous vital sign monitoring, IV access, and supplemental oxygen (if needed) should be established. Seizures may be acutely controlled with rapid-acting medications, like benzodiazepines. If hypocalcemia is suspected as the cause, calcium levels should be measured, and intravenous calcium should be administered.

Option Analysis

❌ Levetiracetam:
Incorrect: Levetiracetam is an antiepileptic medication commonly used for maintenance seizure control. However, this patient's clinical findings are consistent with DiGeorge syndrome, which is often associated with hypocalcemia. Since the patient is presenting with seizures and has a positive Trousseau sign, emergent calcium gluconate administration is crucial.
❌ Ceftriaxone and vancomycin:
Incorrect: Ceftriaxone and vancomycin are used for empiric treatment of meningitis, which typically presents with fever, seizures, headache, neck stiffness, and positive Brudzinski and Kernig signs. However, this patient does not have most of these features, and the clinical findings are more consistent with DiGeorge syndrome. The presence of seizures and a positive Trousseau sign indicate that hypocalcemia is the primary concern and should be addressed emergently.
✅ Calcium gluconate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain:
Incorrect: A brain MRI is helpful in identifying intracranial masses or other structural causes of seizures. However, in this case, the patient's clinical presentation suggests DiGeorge syndrome associated with severe, symptomatic hypocalcemia. Correcting hypocalcemia is a priority.
❌ Electroencephalogram (EEG):
Incorrect: An EEG is valuable for characterizing seizure activity. However, the clinical findings in this patient are more consistent with DiGeorge syndrome and associated severe, symptomatic hypocalcemia. Correcting hypocalcemia is the priority.

questions.text: A 1-hour-old newborn delivered at 38 weeks’ gestation is evaluated in the nursery. Delivery was uneventful with Apgar scores of 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The parents are recent immigrants, and the mother did not have any prenatal care. No fever, rash, vomiting, or diarrhea were reported during the pregnancy. Family history is non-contributory. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 30/min, blood pressure is 65/36 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Weight and height are at the 10<sup>th</sup> percentile, with head circumference at the 5<sup>th</sup> percentile for age. On physical examination, microcephaly, low-set ears, micrognathia, and wide-spaced nipples are noted. Clenched fists and rocker-bottom feet are seen. A holosystolic murmur is heard. Pulmonary and abdominal exams are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This newborn presents with low birth weight, microcephaly, micrognathia, clenched fists, and rocker-bottom feet, consistent with a diagnosis of trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome).

A thorough history and physical examination are crucial for differentiating potential aneuploidies, which are often recognizable in the neonatal period. Rocker-bottom feet, characterized by a prominent calcaneus, talipes equinovarus, and dorsiflexed toes, are characteristic for trisomy 18. Cutis aplasia (i.e. the absence of a portion of the skin on the scalp) should raise suspicion for trisomy 13. Trisomy 21 is recognized by its characteristic features of hypotonia, brachycephaly, a single palmar crease, and upward-slanting palpebral fissures.

Patients with trisomy 18 often have a history of preterm delivery, poor prenatal and postnatal growth, cardiac anomalies, and developmental delay. Dysmorphic features are common, including microcephaly, prominent occiput, tight palpebral fissures, a narrow nose, a cleft lip or palate, micrognathia, and low-set or malformed ears. Extremities may exhibit clenched fists and overlapping fingers. A chromosome analysis revealing 47+18 confirms the diagnosis.

Option Analysis

❌ Klinefelter syndrome:
Incorrect: Klinefelter syndrome presents with tall stature and delayed puberty, typically becoming apparent in adolescence. This newborn exhibits low birth weight, microcephaly, micrognathia, clenched fists, and rocker-bottom feet, which are characteristic of trisomy 18 (Edwards syndrome).
❌ Trisomy 13:
Incorrect: Trisomy 13 and trisomy 18 share some clinical features, but cutis aplasia is a strong indicator of trisomy 13, whereas rocker-bottom feet are seen in trisomy 18.
✅ Trisomy 18:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Trisomy 21:
Incorrect: Trisomy 21 is often recognized by features of hypotonia, brachycephaly, a single palmar crease, wide-spaced toes, and upward-slanting palpebral fissures. The facial features and rocker-bottom feet observed in this case are more characteristic of trisomy 18 than trisomy 21.
❌ Turner syndrome:
Incorrect: Turner syndrome is characterized by lymphedema, a short, webbed neck, wide-spaced nipples, and congenital heart defects. This newborn has low birth weight, microcephaly, micrognathia, clenched fists, and rocker-bottom feet, features more consistent with trisomy 18.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents to clinic for evaluation of progressive abdominal swelling for eight months. The parents note the swelling seems more noticeable on the left side of the abdomen. The parents report associated fever and night sweats. The pregnancy, birth history, and family history are unremarkable. Medical history is notable for delayed developmental milestones. There is no history of difficulty breathing or changes in bowel habits. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 21/min, blood pressure is 100/57 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Abdominal examination reveals asymmetrical distention, with a non-tender, fixed mass overlying the left hypochondriac region extending to the midline. Ophthalmic examination reveals a partially absent iris bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This child presents with developmental delay, aniridia, and Wilms tumor (presented as the progressive abdominal mass in this case) – all features consistent with WAGR syndrome.

Assessing the patient’s cry and tone can help differentiate the etiology in a patient with a microdeletion. A high-pitched cry is characteristic of cri du chat syndrome, while a low-pitched, gravelly cry is typical of Williams syndrome. In those with a “normal” cry, motor function can further narrow the differential. Neonatal hypotonia suggests Prader-Willi syndrome, while severe ataxia points to Angelman syndrome. Velocardiofacial (or DiGeorge) syndrome and Wilms/WAGR syndrome should be considered if there are no signs of motor dysfunction. In these cases, aniridia is more suggestive of Wilms/WAGR syndrome, while hypertelorism, cleft lip/palate, and micrognathia are more indicative of velocardiofacial (or DiGeorge) syndrome.

WAGR syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by a deletion of 11p13 and is associated with Wilms tumor (a malignant embryonal renal tumor that usually presents as an asymptomatic abdominal mass), aniridia, genitourinary anomalies, and a range of intellectual disabilities and developmental delays. Physical exam may show genitourinary anomalies, short stature, and microcephaly. If a deletion of the short arm of chromosome 11 (11p13) is present, Wilms/WAGR syndrome can be diagnosed.

Option Analysis

❌ Angelman syndrome:
Incorrect: Angelman syndrome is characterized by severe ataxia, seizures, absent speech, inappropriate laughter or smiling, and intellectual disability. However, the abdominal mass, developmental delays, and aniridia in this case are more consistent with WAGR syndrome.
❌ CHARGE syndrome:
Incorrect: CHARGE syndrome is associated with coloboma, heart defects, choanal atresia, restricted growth, genital abnormalities, and ear abnormalities. However, the abdominal mass, developmental delays, and aniridia in this case are more consistent with WAGR syndrome.
❌ Digeorge syndrome:
Incorrect: DiGeorge syndrome presents with characteristic facial features, cardiac anomalies, immunodeficiency, speech and language difficulties, and hypocalcemia. However, the abdominal mass, developmental delays, and aniridia in this case are more consistent with WAGR syndrome.
✅ WAGR syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Williams syndrome:
Incorrect: Williams syndrome presents with a low-pitched, gravelly cry, cardiac anomalies, intellectual disabilities, and characteristic facial features. However, the abdominal mass, developmental delays, and aniridia in this case are more consistent with WAGR syndrome.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic for a routine check-up. She reports feeling well and has no concerns. The patient is sexually active with one partner and uses condoms regularly. She does not have fever, fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, vaginal discharge, or gastrointestinal issues. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she has no known chronic illnesses. For the last three months, the patient has been using intravenous opiates. Vitals are within normal limits. There is no pharyngeal erythema, oral lesions or cervical lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. No rashes are seen on the skin. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
