The HIV-1/2 antigen/antibody combination immunoassay is the recommended initial screening test for human immunodeficiency (HIV) infection because it can detect both HIV-1 and HIV-2 antibodies as well as the HIV-1 p24 antigen, allowing for the identification of both acute and established infections. The inclusion of the p24 antigen increases the sensitivity of the test during the early stages of infection when antibodies may not yet be detectable. Screening for HIV infection is recommended for all patients between the ages of 13 and 65 as part of their routine health care. All patients with risk factors should also be offered screening. 

The diagnostic workup for an adult who is due for screening or who has symptoms consistent with HIV infection begins with taking a thorough history to identify risk factors and clinical signs suggestive of HIV. The initial laboratory test of choice is the HIV-1/2 antigen/antibody combination immunoassay, which detects both HIV antibodies and the p24 antigen, allowing for the identification of both acute and established infections. If this test is positive, it should be followed by an HIV-1/HIV-2 antibody differentiation immunoassay to confirm the diagnosis and distinguish between HIV-1 and HIV-2 infection. In cases where the initial combination immunoassay is non-reactive but there is suspicion for recent infection (e.g. known exposure or acute symptoms), an HIV-1 nucleic acid test (NAT) should be performed to attempt to detect the virus during the early window period. Patients with a positive combination immunoassay but negative or indeterminate differentiation test should also have HIV RNA testing.        

Option Analysis

❌ Qualitative HIV-1 nucleic acid test (NAT):
Incorrect: The HIV-1 NAT is highly sensitive and can detect HIV RNA shortly after exposure, but it is not typically used as the initial screening test due to its higher cost and complexity compared to the combination immunoassay.  
❌ HIV Western blot testing:
Incorrect: The Western blot is used as a confirmatory test following a positive initial screening test but is no longer recommended as a standalone initial screening tool due to lower sensitivity for detecting early HIV infection.  
✅ HIV-1/2 antigen/antibody combination immunoassay:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ CD4 count:
Incorrect: The CD4 count measures immune function and helps monitor the progression of HIV infection, but it is not used for initial HIV screening because it does not directly detect the presence of the virus or HIV antibodies.  
❌ Quantitative HIV ribonucleic acid (RNA) testing:
Incorrect: Quantitative HIV RNA testing is done through nucleic acid amplification (HIV-1 NAT) and can be used to detect HIV when very early infection is suspected (i.e. less than 2 weeks) and combination antibody/antigen testing is indeterminate. It can also be used to monitor response to treatment. Combination immunoassay would be the preferred initial test for this patient.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man comes to the emergency room for evaluation of chest pain and shortness of breath. He endorses using intranasal cocaine daily, and his last use was three hours prior to arrival. Temperature is 100 °F (37.7°C), pulse is 100 bpm, blood pressure is 200/120 mmHg, and SpO2 is 99%. The patient appears agitated and irritable. On physical examination, the pupils are mydriatic, and the patient is sweating profusely. Oral mucosa appears moist, and the nasal mucosa is atrophic. Cardiopulmonary exam is unremarkable. The patient moves all four extremities to command with normal deep tendon reflexes. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with ST depression and T wave inversions in I, avL, V5 and V6. He is treated with IV benzodiazepines and undergoes percutaneous intervention. His blood pressure two hours later is 190/100 mmHg. He complains of blurry vision and an occipital headache. Administration of which of the following medications is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with coronary ischemia in the setting of recent cocaine use. Following the procedure, he suffers from features consistent with a hypertensive emergency requiring rapid titration of blood pressure. The most appropriate medication to use in this setting is a vasodilator--such as nitroprusside.

Cocaine is a potent psychostimulant that acts by blocking the reuptake of biogenic amines like norepinephrine, serotonin and dopamine. Cocaine can precipitate coronary ischemia via vasospasm of coronary arteries and subsequent thrombus formation. The treatment of acute cocaine intoxication involves management of severe or symptomatic hypertension and psychomotor agitation, in addition to treatment of cocaine-associated myocardial infarction. Hypertensive emergencies can occur following cocaine use and is characterised by elevated blood pressure with evidence of end organ damage (acute kidney injury, myocardial ischemia, stroke-like symptoms, encephalopathy). In this setting, administration of venodilators such as nitroprusside, nitroglycerin, or phentolamine is appropriate.

Notably, beta blockers are contraindicated in the treatment of cocaine-induced hypertension, as administration can result in uninhibited alpha adrenergic stimulation (which can worsen the vasospastic event).  

Option Analysis

✅ Nitroprusside:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Beta blockers are contraindicated in the treatment of cocaine intoxication, as administration may result in unopposed alpha adrenergic stimulation--worsening coronary ischemia.
❌ Amlodipine:
Incorrect: Calcium channel blockers are used in the treatment of primary hypertension, as they can cause vasodilation. These drugs typically have a longer onset of action and hence are not first line agents in the treatment of hypertensive emergencies.
❌ Hydrochlorothiazide:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics are used in the treatment of essential hypertension in patients with normal kidney function. It is not the agent of choice for hypertensive emergencies.
❌ Alteplase:
Incorrect: Alteplase is a thrombolytic medication. This patient presents with features concerning for hypertensive emergency--requiring administration of antihypertensive agents.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner for evaluation of altered mental status. His partner states the patient woke up today with knee pain, for which he took an “over-the-counter pain reliever” and his prescription hydrocodone-acetaminophen. Several hours later, the partner noticed he was less responsive and unaware of where he was. The patient has a history of chronic lower back pain and chronic alcohol use. On physical examination, the patient is not oriented and responds only to pain. The patient grimaces with palpation of the right upper quadrant. AST and ALT are 2136 and 2467 IU/L, respectively. Which of the following is the most appropriate therapeutic treatment for this patient's clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, right upper quadrant tenderness, and elevated liver enzymes consistent with acute hepatic injury and encephalopathy secondary to acetaminophen overdose. Most cases of acetaminophen toxicity are due to intentional ingestion of large amounts of acetaminophen; however, some patients develop toxicity unintentionally via ingestion of acetaminophen from multiple sources or via underlying hepatic dysfunction (e.g. chronic alcohol use).

Acetaminophen metabolism at therapeutic doses occurs through glucuronidation and sulfation in the liver, which yields non-toxic products that are eliminated through urine. A minimal amount of acetaminophen is converted by CYP450 to the toxic N-acetyl-p-benzoquinone imine (NAPQI); however, this compound is quickly eliminated by combining with the substrate glutathione.

In case of overdose, glucuronidation and sulfation pathways become saturated, leading to increased metabolism by CYP450 and production of NAPQI. The high amount of NAPQI depletes glutathione, with subsequent NAPQI accumulation, resulting in hepatic necrosis and acute liver failure.

First-line treatment for acetaminophen toxicity is N-acetylcysteine (NAC). NAC is fully protective to the liver; it exerts its protective effects by replenishing glutathione, increasing detoxification of NAPQI, and thus preventing further hepatocyte injury and necrosis.



Option Analysis

✅ N-Acetylcysteine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Activated charcoal:
Incorrect: Activated charcoal may be used to treat acetaminophen overdose when the patient is alert and protecting their airway and ingestion was within one hour of presentation. Activated charcoal should be avoided in this patient due to the risk of aspiration injury.
❌ Sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Sodium bicarbonate is an alkaline solution that is used in the treatment of salicylates and tricyclic antidepressants toxicity. It has no role in the management of acetaminophen toxicity.
❌ Orogastric lavage :
Incorrect: Orogastric lavage is not effective for the treatment of acetaminophen toxicity.
❌ Whole bowel irrigation.:
Incorrect: Whole bowel irrigation, like orogastric lavage, is not effective for the treatment of acetaminophen toxicity.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of nausea, vomiting, muscle weakness, and confusion. The symptoms began two days ago. Review of his medical record reveals that he has a recent diagnosis of depression for which fluoxetine therapy was initiated four-weeks ago by his psychiatrist. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), pulse is 78/min, and respiratory rate is 15/min and blood pressure is 117/78 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient has difficulty standing due to generalized weakness. Laboratory studies are as follows:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Sodium  118 mEq/L 
 Blood Urea Nitrogen  15 mg/dL 
 Creatinine  0.8 mg/dL 
 Glucose  105 mg/dL 
 Serum Osmolarity   241 mOsm/kg 
 Urine Osmolality  405 mOsm/kg 

Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient is having severe symptomatic hyponatremia (nausea, vomiting, muscle weakness and confusion). He takes fluoxetine, a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) that can sometimes lead to syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) by increasing pituitary ADH secretion as a side effect.  

Laboratory findings in SIADH include low serum osmolality and high urine osmolality. This is because excess ADH increases water reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubules, resulting in water retention. In turn, the body reduces aldosterone production, which increases urinary sodium excretion to help eliminate some of the excess water. The net result is euvolemic hyponatremia.  

Patients with SIADH are encouraged to restrict fluid intake to 800 ml/day or less. For asymptomatic patients or patients with mild symptoms, salt tablets can be used. In more severe cases, as in this vignette, hypertonic saline is used to correct the hyponatremia. A loop diuretic can be used to supplement the salt tablets or hypertonic saline.  

Serum sodium levels should be corrected by no more than 10 mmol/L within 24 hours. Overly rapid correction can cause central pontine myelinolysis, which presents with symptoms including acute paralysis, dysphagia, and dysarthria.  



Option Analysis

❌ Initiation of 0.9% saline infusion:
Incorrect: Isotonic 0.9% saline is not recommended in patients with SIADH because patients with SIADH have low aldosterone levels, which causes sodium in the saline to be excreted, and high ADH levels, which causes water in the saline to be retained. The net result is worsening hyponatremia.
✅ Initiation of 3% saline infusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Administer furosemide:
Incorrect: Loop diuretics are sometimes used to potentiate the treatment of SIADH. The loop diuretics prevent solute reabsorption in the thick ascending loop of Henle, thereby preventing formation of the medullary concentration gradient. This helps increase the amount of free water lost in urine. However, loop diuretics alone are generally insufficient and are not considered the first-line therapy.
❌ Administer tolvaptan:
Incorrect: Vasopressin antagonists, such as tolvaptan and conivaptan, have been shown to be effective in improving sodium levels in hyponatremic patients. However, the agent has the risk of correcting hyponatremia too rapidly, potentially causing severe neurologic injury. As a result, vasopressin antagonists are generally reserved for patients who have remained hyponatremic despite other interventions.
❌ Emergent hemo-dialysis:
Incorrect: Emergent hemodialysis may rarely be indicated in the treatment of hyponatremia in patients with kidney failure. However, this patient has blood urine nitrogen and creatinine levels within normal range, indicating that the kidneys are functioning normally. Dialysis is not recommended in patients with hyponatremia who have normal-functioning kidneys.

questions.text:
A 65-year old man with a history of severe depression is brought to the emergency department by his partner after she found him unconscious on the bathroom floor. The patient’s partner suspects the patient may have attempted suicide, as she found empty pill bottles next to him. Temperature is 38.1 C° (100.5 F°), pulse is 110/minute, and blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. On physical examination, the pupils are dilated, his skin appears flushed, and bowel sounds are decreased. ECG is shown below. During the evaluation, the patient has a generalized tonic-clonic seizure, which terminates with administration of lorazepam. Which of the following interventions is most appropriate given this patient’s clinical presentation?


Reproduced from: wikipedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a new onset seizure, anticholinergic findings (e.g., flushed skin, mydriasis, urinary retention), and alpha-1 blockade side effects (hypotension). In addition, the ECG strip demonstrates QRS widening. Together, this constellation of findings is consistent with tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) overdose and warrants immediate treatment.

TCAs have a narrow therapeutic-index, and overdose can be lethal, primarily owing to cardiotoxicity.  An ECG must be obtained in all patients with suspected TCA toxicity, and it will typically demonstrate QRS widening (>100msec) due to blockage of fast Na channels in cardiac myocytes.

Sodium bicarbonate is indicated in the treatment of TCA overdose in patients who have seizures, hypotension, or QRS widening (>100msec). Administration of sodium bicarbonate protects against arrhythmia generation, improves the blood pressure, and increases the seizure threshold. Activated charcoal can be administered within two hours following TCA ingestion; however, this treatment can only be given with a secure airway, to protect against aspiration.

The effects of sodium bicarbonate in treating TCA toxicity are due to two primary mechanisms:

  1.  Increasing serum pH: TCAs are weak bases, and an acidic environment facilitates the formation of the ionized form of TCA, thus potentiating its toxic effects. By increasing the serum pH, less of the ionized form of TCA will be present, thus decreasing the active form of TCAs. 
  2.  Increasing serum sodium: TCA inhibits the influx of sodium into the cardiac myocytes and conductive systems in phase 0 of the action potential, thus slowing the depolarization of myocardial cells and prolonging the QRS complex. Providing additional sodium in the extracellular space can potentially reverse the inhibition of fast sodium channels.
PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Sodium bicarbonate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Glucagon:
Incorrect: Glucagon is used in the treatment of beta blocker and calcium channel blocker overdose. It has no role in the treatment of tricyclic antidepressant toxicity.
❌ Atropine:
Incorrect: Atropine is an anticholinergic medication used in the treatment of cholinergic toxicity. Administration of this medication may mitigate the anticholinergic effects of tricyclic antidepressants; however, it has no role in mitigating the lethal cardiovascular toxicity of this medication class.
❌ Supportive care:
Incorrect: This patient presents with features consistent with tricyclic antidepressant overdose. The ECG shows a wide QRS complex, which mandates treatment with sodium bicarbonate.
❌ N-acetylcysteine:
Incorrect: N-acetylcysteine is indicated for treatment of acetaminophen toxicity, not tricyclic antidepressant overdose.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man is being evaluated for hematuria following urinary catheterization. The patient was hospitalized four days ago with severe chest pain and left lower limb swelling, and he was subsequently diagnosed with venous thromboembolism. The patient was admitted to the floor and initiated on heparin anticoagulation therapy. Today, the nursing staff noted bright red blood following urinary catheterization. The patient’s past medical history includes chronic kidney disease, for which he receives dialysis on Monday, Wednesday, and Friday. The patient’s blood pressure is 120/75 mmHg, heart rate is 100/minute, and respirations are 18/minute. The patient’s serum analysis is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

Hemoglobin   9 g/dL 
 Hematocrit  45% 
 Platelet count  190,000/mm3 
 Leukocyte count  8,000/mm3 
 International normalized ratio (INR)  1.6 
 Activated partial thromboplastin time (PTT)   114 seconds
questions.solution:
This patient on heparin therapy for venous thromboembolism has developed hematuria, indicative of  supratherapeutic anticoagulation. Patients who develop excessive bleeding while taking heparin are provided with protamine sulfate--a heparin reversal agent.






Heparin exerts its anticoagulant effect by activating antithrombin III, which then inhibits factor X and factor II, thereby preventing clot formation. Excessive anticoagulation with heparin can be life-threatening and lead to severe bleeding. Therefore, patients taking heparin are monitored by measuring the  activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).

Protamine sulfate is the first-line treatment for reversal of heparin overdose or toxicity. This negatively charged molecule binds to positively charged heparin molecules and prevents their action. Protamine sulfate can reverse the effects of heparin within seconds of administration.

Option Analysis

✅ Administration of protamine sulfate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Administration of Vitamin K:
Incorrect: Vitamin K is used to reverse the anticoagulant effects of warfarin, which is not typically used for the treatment of acute venous thromboembolism. Moreover, administration of vitamin K is unlikely to be of any acute clinical benefit.
❌ Administration of prothrombin complex concentrate:
Incorrect: Prothrombin complex concentrate is used for immediate reversal of warfarin anticoagulant effects in cases of life-threatening bleeding. It is not first-line for heparin reversal.
❌ Administration of fresh frozen plasma:
Incorrect: Like prothrombin complex concentrate, fresh frozen plasma is also used to immediately reverse the anticoagulant effects of warfarin in actively bleeding patients. It is not the first-line medication to use for heparin reversal.
❌ Administration of andexanet alfa:
Incorrect: Andexanet alfa is used to reverse the anticoagulant effects of direct factor Xa inhibitors (e.g., apixaban, rivaroxaban). Direct factor Xa inhibitors are not used in patients with chronic kidney disease, due to increased risk of bleeding.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to his primary care physician for evaluation of tremor and ataxia. He is unable to walk without his partner’s assistance in the clinic. In addition, his partner reports “confusion” for the past two days. The patient has a history of severe bipolar disorder, for which he takes lithium. One month ago, he started using an over-the-counter medication for arthritic knee pain. He does not use tobacco or alcohol. Pale mucous membranes are noted on physical examination. Laboratory analysis demonstrates elevated serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen. In addition to intravenous fluids, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment of this patient's clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of bipolar disorder presents with features consistent with lithium toxicity, given his neurological symptoms (e.g., ataxia, confusion) and abnormal kidney function. Lithium is the first-line treatment for bipolar disorder; however, it has a very narrow therapeutic index. This medication is neither metabolized nor bound to serum proteins, and the elimination of lithium occurs primarily via the kidneys.

Acute lithium toxicity typically occurs after intentional ingestion (e.g. suicidal attempt), and it is clinically characterized by gastrointestinal manifestations (e.g., nausea, vomiting, diarrhea) followed by neurological manifestations (e.g. confusion). Chronic lithium toxicity, however, occurs with decreased elimination of lithium by the kidneys. The kidneys treat sodium and lithium similarly, and any change in  urinary sodium reabsorption (e.g., dehydration, renal insufficiency, excessive exercise) will also lead to increased reabsorption of lithium. Ultimately, this lowers serum lithium clearance and predisposes to overdose. In addition, some medications decrease renal clearance of lithium, including thiazide diuretics, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEI). This patient likely began taking an NSAID for his arthritic knee pain, resulting in decreased lithium clearance and subsequent toxicity.

Clinically, chronic toxicity is characterized by neurological manifestations including ataxia and tremor, in addition to renal insufficiency. In particular, lithium impairs the concentrating effects of the kidneys, inducing nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Patients often demonstrate varying degrees of consciousness, from mild confusion to delirium and coma. Treatment of lithium toxicity begins with administration of intravenous fluids, followed by hemodialysis for patients with severe toxicity or those with evidence of kidney insufficiency.

Option Analysis

✅ Hemodialysis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Activated charcoal:
Incorrect: Activated charcoal is not indicated in lithium toxicity, unless coingestion is suspected. Lithium does not bind well to charcoal.
❌ Supportive care:
Incorrect: This patient's kidney function indicates some level of renal insufficiency from lithium toxicity. In this setting, hemodialysis is indicated in order to clear lithium from circulation.
❌ Sodium bicarbonate:
Incorrect: Sodium bicarbonate is indicated in the treatment of tricyclic antidepressant and salicylate toxicity. It has no role in lithium overdose.
❌ Peritoneal dialysis:
Incorrect: Peritoneal dialysis should not supersede hemodialysis in patients with lithium toxicity. Should hemodialysis not be available, peritoneal dialysis can be considered.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents following two convulsive episodes. Over the last week, the patient has been refusing to eat and stays up all night working on his science fair project. Tonight, his parents found him violently shaking on the floor of his room.  The patient has depression and currently takes bupropion. His younger brother has ADHD, for which he takes methylphenidate. The patient drinks 4-5 beers with his friends on the weekend. Temperature is 100°F (37.7°C), pulse is 110 bpm, and blood pressure is 166/90 mmHg. The patient appears agitated and irritable. On physical examination, the pupils are mydriatic, and the patient appears diaphoretic. Oral mucosa is moist, and a small tongue laceration is present. The patient moves all four extremities to command and has 2+ deep tendon reflexes. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with suspicion for first-time seizures in the setting of a hyperadrenergic state. His clinical history is suspicious for sympathomimetic coingestion (likely his brother's methylphenidate), given his breakthrough seizure while on bupropion (this atypical antidepressant lowers the seizure threshold).

Amphetamine intoxication can cause neurological effects which include euphoria, impulsivity and delusions. In severe cases, it can cause seizures that occur typically within 24 hours of ingestion. Treatment for agitation, aggressive behaviour and seizures caused by amphetamine intoxication involves the administration of intravenous benzodiazepines (midazolam, diazepam or lorazepam). When high doses of benzodiazepines fail to control agitation or seizures, first generation neuroleptics like haloperidol can be used as second-line agents. Physical restraints should be avoided unless the patient poses a threat to himself or staff.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lorazepam:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone is used to reverse opioid intoxication, not amphetamine overdose.
❌ Acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Febrile seizures are common in children between 2-5 years of age, but fever is an unlikely cause of seizure in this patient. Acetaminophen may be administered for treatment of this febrile seizure.
❌ Phentolamine:
Incorrect: Phentolamine may be administered for treatment of the noradrenergic state associated with amphetamine abuse; however, benzodiazepines are considered first line.
❌ Cyproheptadine:
Incorrect: Cyproheptadine, a serotonin antagonist, may be used to treat serotonin syndrome. This condition can cause psychomotor agitation and seizures; however, neurological examination typically demonstrates hypertonia and clonus.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to a week of reduced concentration at work and a persistent headache. The patient recently quit smoking cigarettes and is requesting medication to assist in her abstinence. The patient has a history of major depressive disorder, generalized anxiety disorder, gastroesophageal reflux disease and allergic rhinitis. Her current medication regimen includes pantoprazole and over-the-counter nasal decongestants. She smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for ten years. The patient appears irritable. Temperature is 98 °F (36.6 °C), pulse is 96 bpm, and blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg. Administration of which of the following medications is the best next step of management in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with classic features of nicotine withdrawal including a history of chronic tobacco use and recent cessation, dysphoria, increased appetite, hypersomnia, poor concentration and weight gain. Nicotine is a potent psychoactive stimulant that acts as a ganglionic and central nervous system stimulant. Once a patient with chronic tobacco use abstains from smoking, symptoms of nicotine withdrawal arise within as little as several hours. Symptoms include weight gain, dysphoria, hypersomnia, increased appetite, poor concentration and a craving for tobacco.

Management of smoking cessation is most effective when it involves the combination of both behavioral and pharmacological interventions. Recommended first-line pharmacologic therapy includes varenicline or a combination of two nicotine replacement therapies. Nicotine replacement therapy in the form of nicotine gum, patches, lozenges or nasal spray have been found to be effective alternative therapies in smoking cessation. Varencicline is a nicotinic acetylcholine receptor partial agonist that is a first-line agent used for smoking cessation. The atypical antidepressant bupropion is also commonly used as a pharmacological agent for smoking cessation--particularly in patients with a history of major depressive disorder. This medication should be avoided in patients with a history or risk factors for developing seizures.  

Option Analysis

✅ Varenicline:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Risperidone:
Incorrect: Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic agent that acts as a dopamine antagonist. This medication is used in the treatment of schizophrenia, not for smoking cessation.
❌ Buspirone:
Incorrect: Buspirone stimulates serotonin receptors and is used in the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder. It is not used in the treatment of nicotine withdrawal syndrome and smoking cessation.
❌ Phenelzine:
Incorrect: Phenelzine is a monoamine oxidase inhibitor that can be used in the management of treatment resistant depression and atypical depression.
❌ Mirtazapine:
Incorrect: Mirtazapine is an atypical antidepressant--it is not indicated for the treatment of nicotine withdrawal syndrome and smoking cessation.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for evaluation after a suicide attempt. Per report, the patient's partner broke up with her, and she decided to end her life by overdosing on an unknown quantity of “some pills.”  The patient is currently complaining of blurry vision and confusion. Her temperature is 38.9 C° (102 F° ), respirations are 20/minute,  pulse is 125/minute, and blood pressure is 125/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is not oriented to place or time. The pupils are dilated and nonreactive to light. Her skin appears flushed and dry, and bowel sounds are absent. An ECG demonstrates sinus tachycardia. She does not have evidence of clonus. Administration of which of the following medications is the most appropriate intervention given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This 17-year-old female presents following an ingestion of an unknown quantity or type of medication with dry flushed skin, mydriasis, tachycardia, fever and decreased bowel sounds. Together, these findings suggest an anticholinergic toxidrome, which is best treated with physostigmine.

Anticholinergic toxicity is a medical emergency and, without proper treatment, can be fatal. The manifestations of anticholinergic toxicity result from inhibition of the central and peripheral muscarinic acetylcholine receptors, and the clinical presentation includes delirium, confusion, agitation, dry flushed skin, decreased bowel sounds, and mydriasis.



First-line treatment for anticholinergic toxicity is physostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor. Acetylcholinesterase breaks down acetylcholine at the synaptic cleft, and inhibition of this enzyme, increases the acetylcholine bioavailability--resulting in reversal of anticholinergic symptoms. Physostigmine is active in both the central and peripheral nervous system, thus reversing muscarinic inhibition centrally and peripherally. Additional therapeutic measures include hydration, cooling for hyperthermia, and sodium bicarbonate for treatment of wide complex dysrhythmias.

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Physostigmine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Atropine:
Incorrect: Atropine is an anticholinergic agent used to treat acute cholinergic toxicity (e.g. organophosphate toxicity). Patients with cholinergic toxicity present with increased bowel sounds, hypotension, bradycardia, and miosis.
❌ Naloxone:
Incorrect: Naloxone is an opioid antagonist used to treat opioid overdose. Although patients with opioid intoxication may have disorientation and decreased bowel sounds, the respiratory rate is expected to decrease, and blood pressure is typically low. Addition, patients have miosis, not mydriatic pupils.
❌ Cyproheptadine:
Incorrect:  Cyproheptadine is a medication used to treat serotonin syndrome. While similar to anticholinergic toxicity, serotonin syndrome often presents with clonus, which is absent in this patient.
❌ Hemodialysis:
Incorrect: Hemodialysis is used in the treatment for a variety of intoxications, including lithium and aspirin. It has no role in the treatment of anticholinergic toxicity.

questions.text: A 17-year old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of altered mental status. Earlier this morning, the patient was complaining of ringing in his ears, abdominal pain, and vomiting. His parents report he has seemed more depressed lately, and they are worried he may have taken something to hurt himself. Per EMS, the patient was found with an empty pill bottle belonging to his grandmother. Temperature is 38.5 C° (101.3 F°), pulse is 106/minute, respirations are 10/minute, and blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. On physical examination the patient is minimally responsive to pain, pupils are reactive and equal bilaterally, and no clonus is appreciated. During the evaluation, the patient has a generalized tonic-clonic seizure, which terminates with administration of lorazepam. Administration of which of the following medications is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s suspected medication toxicity?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status, fever, tachypnea, and a witnessed tonic-clonic seizure. In addition, the patient’s endorsement of tinnitus, central nervous system disruption (e.g., agitation, confusion, seizure, tinnitus), and gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g., nausea and vomiting, abdominal pain) are consistent with salicylate intoxication.



Management of salicylate poisoning involves multiple steps, including typical resuscitation measures, such as administration of intravenous fluids, airway securement, and electrolyte correction. Dextrose is used to treat central nervous system hypoglycemia, which is common in patients with salicylate poisoning, even when serum glucose is normal.

Alkalinization of the urine via intravenous sodium bicarbonate administration remains a cornerstone for treatment of salicylate poisoning. Administration of sodium bicarbonate increases serum and urinary pH,  favoring the formation of charged salicylate molecules. Charged salicylate less readily crosses the blood-brain-barrier and instead becomes excreted in the urine at a rate ten-fold greater than uncharged salicylate. Additional measures include benzodiazepines for seizures management and hemodialysis in the setting of severe salicylate toxicity.

PS: If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.



Option Analysis

✅ Sodium bicarbonate:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cyproheptadine:
Incorrect: Cyproheptadine is a medication used to treat serotonin syndrome. While similar to anticholinergic toxicity, serotonin syndrome often presents with clonus, which is absent in this patient.
❌ Deferoxamine:
Incorrect: Deferoxamine is indicated in iron toxicity, but it has no role in the management of salicylate toxicity.
❌ N-acetylcysteine:
Incorrect: N-acetylcysteine is used in patients with acetaminophen intoxication, not salicylate toxicity.
❌ Fomepizole:
Incorrect: Fomepizole is used in treatment of toxic alcohols ingestion (e.g., methanol, ethylene glycol). It has no role in the management of salicylate toxicity.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of chest pain and shortness of breath. The patient’s chest pain is retrosternal and began two hours ago. He does not use tobacco but consumes alcohol with his friends on the weekends. His last drink was at a party last night where he also  insufflated a white, crystalline substance. Temperature is 100 °F (37.7°C), pulse is 110 bpm, blood pressure is 170/90 mmHh, and SpO2 is 99%. The patient appears agitated and irritable. On physical examination, the pupils are mydriatic, and the patient appears diaphoretic. Cardiac auscultation demonstrates a normal S1 and S2 without murmurs, rubs or gallops. The patient moves all four extremities to command and has normal deep tendon reflexes. ECG shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features of cocaine intoxication and associated chest pain, which requires prompt treatment with a benzodiazepine-type medication such as lorazepam. Cocaine is a psychostimulant that is commonly insufflated and works mechanistically via blocking the reuptake of biogenic amines including serotonin, dopamine and norepinephrine. It also enhances the release of excitatory neurotransmitters glutamate and aspartate--predisposing patients to seizures.

Clinical effects of cocaine use include psychomotor agitation, hyperarousal, agitation, hypertension, tachycardia, pupillary dilation, and seizures. Complications of cocaine intoxication include myocardial ischemia, ventricular arrhythmias, aortic dissection, pulmonary edema and focal neurologic defects. Myocardial injury is often secondary to vasospasm of coronary arteries with subsequent thrombus formation. Patients with acute cocaine intoxication should be treated with intravenous benzodiazepines, and those with acute coronary syndrome should be administered antiplatelets and percutaneous coronary intervention if clinically indicated.

 




Option Analysis

✅ Administration of lorazepam:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ CT pulmonary angiography:
Incorrect: CT pulmonary angiography is typically used to evaluate for the presence of a pulmonary embolism. This patient requires treatment of his cocaine intoxication before advanced imaging.
❌ Exercise stress test:
Incorrect: Exercise stress tests are indicated for risk stratification and evaluation of stable ischemic heart disease. This patient requires treatment of his cocaine intoxication before advanced imaging.
❌ Colchicine and aspirin:
Incorrect: Treatment of acute pericarditis involves administration of NSAIDS and colchicine. ECG in acute pericarditis is characterized by diffuse ST segment elevation and PR segment depression in limb and precordial leads.
❌ Esophagography with water soluble contrast:
Incorrect: Esophageal perforation is characterized by chest pain, fever and crepitus over the chest wall.  It can follow an episode of prolonged effort during retching.This patient requires treatment of his cocaine intoxication before advanced imaging.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of intermittent fevers, chills, malaise, and fatigue for the past month. The symptoms develop sporadically, last anywhere from 1-4 days, and spontaneously resolve. The patient returned from a safari trip in Africa 2-months ago. He received chemoprophylaxis with chloroquine during the trip and continued it for four weeks after returning. Past medical history is unremarkable. Temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 103/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mmHg. Physical examination shows pale conjunctiva and an enlarged spleen. Peripheral blood smear shows trophozoites and schizonts. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient’s infection?

choices.text: Release of dormant hypnozoites from hepatocytes
Infection with parasites resistant to chloroquine
Mosquito bites after returning to the United States
Unprotected intercourse with a new partner

questions.solution:
This patient presents with an irregular fever pattern, chills, and myalgias after returning from a malaria-endemic area. In combination with the trophozoites and schizonts seen on peripheral smear, these findings are concerning for infection by chloroquine-resistant Plasmodium falciparum.

Chloroquine is an antimalarial drug and a quinoline derivative. Other quinoline derivatives include quinidine, mefloquine, and primaquine. These medications work by entering the Plasmodium and accumulating in their food vacuoles. Here, they bind to heme and prevent its conversion into hemozoin. Heme is toxic to the Plasmodium, and its accumulation eventually leads to their death.

Chloroquine is one of the most commonly used antimalarial medications and is an effective blood schizonticide (kills Plasmodium found in erythrocytes). It is effective against all species of Plasmodium. Still, its widespread use has caused P. falciparum in many parts of South America, Africa, and Asia to develop resistance via a membrane efflux pump that can pump out drug molecules. In these regions, mefloquine, quinidine, and quinine can be used as the main schizontocidal medication.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Release of dormant hypnozoites from hepatocytes:
Incorrect: Plasmodium ovale and Plasmodium vivax have a dormant hepatic phase (hypnozoite) that may reactivate in patients several months after returning from a malaria-endemic region. However, the irregular pattern of this patient’s symptoms is more concerning for Plasmodium falciparum infection, which does not have a dormant hepatic phase.  
✅ Infection with parasites resistant to chloroquine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Mosquito bites after returning to the United States:
Incorrect: Malaria has been eradicated mainly from the United States. Individuals who develop malaria in the United States usually acquire the infection in different countries.  
❌ Unprotected intercourse with a new partner:
Incorrect: Syphilis, caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum, is usually transmitted via unprotected sexual intercourse. Patients can develop a chancre (painless ulcer) early in the disease course. In combination with trophozoites and schizonts on peripheral smear, fever and chills are more suggestive of an alternative diagnosis.  
❌ Inadequate duration of chemoprophylaxis:
Incorrect: Chemoprophylaxis against malarial infection should begin at least 2-weeks before traveling to an endemic region, be continued during the trip, and discontinued 4-weeks after returning. This patient completed the entire chemoprophylaxis regimen.

questions.text: A 88-year-old man presents to the emergency department for new-onset confusion. The patient's daughter reports he was in his usual state of health until today when he was noted as “acting funny.” The patient has a past medical history of hypertension,  hyperlipidemia, diabetes, chronic back pain, coronary artery disease, and benign prostatic hyperplasia. His medications include hydrocodone, aspirin, prazosin, amlodipine, simvastatin, metformin, and sildenafil. He is normally alert, awake, and oriented to time, place, and person and requires only some assistance with activities of daily independent living. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.7°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 10/min, blood pressure is 130/64 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination reveals an elderly male who appears confused. He states the year is “1964” and “Gerald Ford is the president of the United States.'' Neurologic examination is otherwise unremarkable. Abdominal examination reveals suprapubic tenderness to palpation, for which he is provided 2 mg of intravenous morphine. Urinalysis demonstrates 3+ bacteria with positive nitrite and leukocyte esterase. During his stay, he attempts to get out of bed several times and begins shouting at the nursing staff. Several attempts at verbal de-escalation, redirection, and reorientation are unsuccessful. Which of the following medications is the most appropriate given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient presents for evaluation of new-onset confusion in a possible urinary tract infection (suprapubic tenderness with bacteriuria and pyuria on urinalysis). His presentation is consistent with agitated delirium, unresponsive to redirection and reorientation. Due to the threat to self, providers, and staff, the next best management step is treating this patient’s agitation, which according to the Beers criteria, includes first-generation antipsychotics like haloperidol.    

The Beers criteria refer to a continuously updated list of potentially inappropriate medications for geriatric patients, primarily due to high risk for adverse events, including delirium, falls, urinary retention, and constipation. According to the most recently updated version of the Beers criteria, general medication classes to avoid in patients in the elderly includes benzodiazepines, antimuscarinic medications (including first-generation antihistamines), opiates, alpha-blockers, NSAIDs, and proton pump inhibitors. A review of this patient’s medication list reveals prescriptions for two medication classes (opiate and alpha-blocker).  

Option Analysis

✅ Haloperidol :
Correct: See Main Explanation.   
❌ Lorazepam :
Incorrect: Administration of lorazepam will likely augment this patient’s delirium. Beer’s criteria recommend avoiding concurrent administration of benzodiazepines and opiates.   
❌ Diphenhydramine :
Incorrect: According to Beer’s criteria, first-generation antihistamines should generally be avoided in patients with delirium, as the antimuscarinic effects of this medication may worsen symptoms.  
❌ Midazolam :
Incorrect: Administration of midazolam will likely augment this patient’s delirium. Beer’s criteria currently recommend avoidance of concurrent administration of both benzodiazepines and opiates.   
❌ Tramadol :
Incorrect: Tramadol, a medication with several mechanisms of action, should be avoided in geriatric patients due to the risk of hyponatremia from a syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion.

questions.text: A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being found altered at home with scattered pill bottles at the bedside. He endorses hearing a persistent “ringing sound” in the ears and has several episodes of nausea and vomiting while being triaged. Past medical history is notable for coronary artery disease, stroke, and hypertension. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), respirations are 26/min, pulse is 104/min, and blood pressure is 145/80 mmHg. A medication overdose is suspected, and the patient is empirically administered sodium bicarbonate to enhance renal drug excretion. Which of the following medications did this patient likely ingest?
questions.solution:
Several medications (e.g., phenobarbital, methotrexate, aspirin) are weak acids. Aspirin is an example of a weak acid in both a charged (deprotonated) and uncharged (protonated) form. The uncharged molecule can quickly move across cellular barriers like the blood-brain barrier. As a result, the uncharged form of the drug can cross the blood-brain barrier, accumulate in the brain, and result in altered mental status and cerebral edema. Moreover, the uncharged form of salicylate can be reabsorbed from the renal collecting system, thereby preventing drug elimination and perpetuating its harmful effects in the setting of an overdose.      

Treatment of overdose with weak acids is often achieved via alkalinization through sodium bicarbonate administration. By increasing systemic pH, salicylate converts to its charged (deprotonated form) and thus cannot rapidly diffuse into the central nervous system, as charged molecules do not easily diffuse across the blood-brain barrier. Alkalinization also results in the trapping of salicylate anions within the renal tubule, preventing back-diffusion across the renal epithelium into c circulation.    

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.   


Option Analysis

✅ Aspirin:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Amitriptyline:
Incorrect: Amitriptyline is an example of a weak base, not a weak acid. Sodium bicarbonate can be used to enhance cardiac stabilization in patients with tricyclic antidepressant overdose. However, it is not used to improve renal excretion.  
❌ Methylphenidate:
Incorrect: Methylphenidate is an example of a weak base, not a weak acid. Administration of ammonium chloride is used to enhance the excretion of weak base drugs.  
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Metoprolol is an example of a weak base, not a weak acid. As a result, ammonium chloride (not sodium bicarbonate) can be administered to enhance drug excretion. Moreover, β-blocker overdose is characterized by bradycardia, not tachycardia.
❌ Atropine:
Incorrect: Atropine is an example of a weak base, not a weak acid. Overdose with atropine is characterized by antimuscarinic symptoms such as tachycardia, increased body temperature, cutaneous flushing, and urinary retention. Furthermore, ammonium chloride (not sodium bicarbonate) can be administered to enhance the excretion of weak base drugs.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband for worsening confusion and lethargy over the past 24 hours. He found multiple empty bottles of acetaminophen on the kitchen counter. The patient states that she was trying to relieve her headache. Past medical history is significant for major depressive disorder. Her only medication is sertraline. Temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), blood pressure is 112/68 mm Hg, pulse is 95/min, respiratory rate is 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, she is drowsy but arousable. Her pupils are 3 mm and reactive. She exhibits asterixis with outstretched arms. Abdominal examination is significant for right upper quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain. Laboratory evaluation shows AST 4500 U/L, ALT 5300 U/L and prolonged INR. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with increasing confusion and lethargy, asterixis, significantly elevated liver enzymes, and a prolonged INR. This clinical presentation, in addition to the discovery of multiple empty bottles of acetaminophen, is suggestive of acetaminophen overdose leading to acute liver failure (liver toxicity and hepatic encephalopathy). N-acetylcysteine (NAC) should be given immediately as it is the antidote to acetaminophen poisoning.

Acetaminophen overdose is a major cause of drug-induced liver injury. When taken in excess, hepatic stores of glutathione, a crucial antioxidant, become depleted. This leads to the accumulation of a harmful metabolite that inflicts damage on hepatocytes. The early stage of overdose manifests as nausea, vomiting, and a general sense of unwellness. As liver damage progresses, clinical features such as hepatic encephalopathy become evident. The administration of N-acetylcysteine (NAC) as soon as possible is crucial. NAC is a precursor to glutathione and promotes non-toxic metabolic pathways, thereby preventing and diminishing liver injury.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administer N-acetylcysteine (NAC):
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Perform hemodialysis:
Incorrect: Hemodialysis is not effective for acetaminophen poisoning, as acetaminophen is metabolized by the liver and not excreted by the kidneys.
❌ Administer activated charcoal:
Incorrect: Activated charcoal can limit acetaminophen absorption if given within 4 hours of ingestion. However, its effectiveness diminishes with delayed presentation as seen in this patient.  
❌ Administer lactulose:
Incorrect: Lactulose is a synthetic sugar used as an osmotic agent to treat hepatic encephalopathy by promoting the excretion of ammonia in the intestines. However, giving N-acetylcysteine immediately is the priority as it can decrease further liver injury and improve mortality in patients with acetaminophen overdose.  
❌ Consult surgery for liver transplantation:
Incorrect: Although the high INR indicates liver synthetic dysfunction and this patient with liver toxicity and encephalopathy has acute liver failure, liver transplantation is not the immediate next step in management. N-acetylcysteine (NAC) treatment remains the priority as it can markedly alter the prognosis and improve mortality from acetaminophen overdose.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents to the emergency department with chest pain. The patient was insufflating a white powder earlier in the evening, and his symptoms developed shortly after that. Temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 144/min, respirations are 22/min, blood pressure is 201/84 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. Physical examination reveals diaphoresis and mydriasis. Which of the following medications is contraindicated, given this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chest pain and significant vital sign derangements, which are suggestive of hypertensive emergency in the setting of alleged cocaine use. ꞵ-blockers like labetalol are contraindicated in managing these patients due to the risk of unopposed α-stimulation.

Indirect sympathomimetics like cocaine work by indirectly increasing the concentration of endogenous catecholamines within the synaptic cleft. In the case of cocaine, the concentration of neurotransmitters, including dopamine, norepinephrine, epinephrine, and serotonin, are elevated. Peripherally, these catecholamines can stimulate postsynaptic α1- and α2-adrenoceptors, resulting in smooth muscle contraction and vasoconstriction. When this occurs in the coronary vasculature, patients often present with symptoms reminiscent of an acute coronary syndrome.

When a β-blocker is administered, the β2-vasodilator influence opposing α-adrenoceptor-mediated vasoconstriction is removed, potentially worsening blood pressure and its subsequent effects on the coronary vasculature.  

Option Analysis

✅ Labetalol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lorazepam:
Incorrect: GABA-agonists such as lorazepam, midazolam, and diazepam are indicated in the management of hypertensive emergencies induced by cocaine use.  
❌ Aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin has been shown to have beneficial effects in managing acute coronary syndrome and should be administered to patients with an underlying suspicion of this condition. It is not contraindicated for patients with chest pain secondary to cocaine use.  
❌ Midazolam:
Incorrect: GABA-agonists such as lorazepam, midazolam, and diazepam are indicated in the management of hypertensive emergencies induced by cocaine use.  
❌ Hydralazine:
Incorrect: Hydralazine is a potent direct-acting vasodilator. It is not the first-line medication to manage hypertensive emergencies secondary to amphetamine use. However, the medication is also not contraindicated.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of nausea and vomiting after swallowing several packets of acetaminophen tablets. The patient swallowed the pills 5 hours ago. Past medical history is significant for major depressive disorder which is being treated with fluoxetine. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows minimal epigastric tenderness. Serum acetaminophen levels are elevated, and the appropriate therapeutic medication is initiated. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of this therapy?

choices.text: Increased conversion of NH3 to ammonium NH4+ in the colon
Induction of vomiting and purging of acetaminophen
Reduction in the absorption of ingested acetaminophen

questions.solution:
Acetaminophen poisoning is the most common cause of acute liver failure in the United States. The recommended maximum daily dose for healthy adults is 3 grams, with higher doses leading to increased risk of toxicity. N-acetylcysteine is the antidote if treatment is sought within 8 hours of ingestion. If a patient presents within 4 hours of ingestion, gastric decontaminating agents, such as oral activated charcoal, is indicated to decrease absorption from the stomach and small intestine.

Normally, the small amounts of toxic NAPQI produced via microsomal metabolism (CYP-450 enzymes) after therapeutic doses of acetaminophen are detoxified by binding to glutathione. NAPQI depletes glutathione, and once glutathione is depleted to approximately one-third of normal levels, NAPQI binds crucial cellular proteins. This results in hepatic cell death, necrosis, and subsequent fulminant liver failure. The amino acid, cysteine, is the main factor limiting the synthesis of glutathione. N-acetylcysteine is a cysteine precursor that is hydrolysed intracellularly to cysteine, thereby replenishing intracellular glutathione.

P.S. If you or someone you know needs this, here's the number for the U.S. National Suicide Prevention Lifeline: 1-800-273-8255 or text HOME to the Crisis Text Line at 741741, or visit www.iasp.info/suicidalthoughts/ for international resources. You are not alone.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Increased conversion of NH3 to ammonium NH4+ in the colon:
Incorrect: Gastric lavage, commonly referred to as 'stomach pumping', is a technique in which stomach contents are removed by repeated administration and aspiration of fluid through an orogastric. It is no longer in routine and it has been replaced in most circumstances by the use of activated charcoal.  
❌ Induction of vomiting and purging of acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Ipecac syrup is a cough syrup that used to be widely administered to induce vomiting. It is no longer recommended in the management of acute toxin ingestion.  
❌ Inhibition of enzyme cytochrome P-450:
Incorrect: Cimetidine, a CYP-450 inhibitor, inhibits the breakdown of acetaminophen into the toxic metabolite NAPQI. Although treatment was useful in animal models, it had minimal effects in a clinical trial where patients were treated with N-acetylcysteine.  
❌ Reduction in the absorption of ingested acetaminophen:
Incorrect: Activated charcoal reduces the absorption of acetaminophen if given within four hours of ingestion. This patient is presenting 5 hours after overdosing, which makes another therapeutic option more beneficial.  
✅ Replenishment of intracellular amino acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man comes to his outpatient provider for evaluation of difficulty chewing. He reports his gums have become red, swollen, and painful. Past medical history is notable for atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. The patient takes multiple medications which his son helps him manage; thus he cannot remember the names of the medications. His younger brother has a history of idiopathic seizures that persisted into adulthood. In the office, the patient’s temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 160/89 mmHg, and pulse is 75/min. Physical exam reveals firm and painful nodular enlargement of the interdental papilla. Cardiovascular, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for this patient’s physical exam findings?
questions.solution:
This patient has physical exam findings consistent with gingival hyperplasia, a side effect classically associated with dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (CCBs). The reason for this is that CCBs are also known to downregulate the degradation of connective tissue fibers; collagenase is essential to connective tissue breakdown, and calcium is essential to collagenase activation. By blocking cytoplasmic uptake of calcium, CCBs disrupt the tissue breakdown pathway. Of note, while gingival hyperplasia can present in patients taking either dihydropyridine or non-dihydropyridine CCBs, it is more strongly associated with dihydropyridine CCBs on board examinations.  

Additional side effects of dihydropyridine CCBs, which primarily act on vascular smooth muscle, include reflex tachycardia as well as flushing, dizziness, and peripheral edema secondary to vasodilation.  

Side effects of non-dihydropyridine CCBs, which primarily act on the heart, include bradycardia, constipation, and hyperprolactinemia.

Option Analysis

❌ Pravastatin:
Incorrect: Statins can treat hyperlipidemia by inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase. Side effects may include hepatotoxicity and myopathy. However, statins would not cause the gingival hyperplasia observed in this patient. 
❌ Phenytoin:
Incorrect: Phenytoin is an anticonvulsant that works by inactivating sodium channels. The medication can cause gingival hyperplasia as a side effect. However, this patient has no history of seizures and hence it would be unlikely that he was prescribed phenytoin.
✅ Nifedipine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Losartan:
Incorrect: Losartan is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. ACE inhibitors are used in the treatment of hypertension and diabetic nephropathy. Side effects include angioedema, coughing, hyperkalemia, and hypotension. However, the medication would not account for the side effects experienced by this patient.
❌ Verapamil:
Incorrect: Verapamil is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker (CCB) that acts primarily on the heart. It can be used to treat tachyarrhythmias, angina, and hypertension. Although verapamil can cause gingival hyperplasia (prevalence: 4.2%), this side effect is more frequently seen in patients taking nifedipine (prevalence: 14%). In general, gingival hyperplasia occurs more frequently in patients taking dihydropyridine CCBs.
